choices: Beliamon ended up returning back to their old abodes at the Temple of Earth.
Somewhere Kouji had never seen before.
13412211211211112211221212.content:
"Beliamon!" exclaimed a voice sharply, as her body was shaken a little too vigorously by unseen hands. In an instant, the dreamworld crafted out of her memories shattered. The vivid colors of her recollections faded and the dull grays of the ruined city slowly returned.

Suddenly, Beliamon's eyes snapped open, revealing the bland gray expanse of the empty sky and. . .

Beliamon's head was resting on something warm and comfortable. . . and she found herself looking up at the dark haired boy, who was standing near her side, looking down with his blue eyes that somehow seemed much deeper than before. Beliamon thought for a second that she detected tension in his face, and saw the slightest thin line underneath both his eyes.

"Uhh. . ." Beliamon moaned groggily as she turned her face around, ". . .Kouji?"

Kouji let out a deep breath as his face softened and became more at ease. A small smile touched his lips as he nodded his head. Then he turned around, gazing toward the distance, and was silent for a few moments.

"You. . . you were out cold for quite a while," he finally said.

"Oh, was I?" Beliamon remarked rather quickly and bittersweetly, not forgetting that Kouji had witnessed her little breakdown from before, something she'd have hoped she could have hid from him. Beliamon hoped that Kouji would have somehow forgotten that. . . and Beliamon wished she could do a little forgetting of her own as well.

Those memories. . . they were all still well and alive in her head. And this rotting corpse of a city reeked of nostaglia and threatened to tap into her mind and provoke the memories into exposing themselves again.

Her head ached and swam around, she could still feel it pound and reverberate deeply in her mind. Her entire body seemed racked with fatigue brought about either from her hysterical emotions from before or taking a rough fall. Beliamon shook her head and ran a hand over her forehead dotted with droplets of chilled sweat. She could have really benefited off of one of the few healing spells she knew to help her get along, although they'd probably put her to sleep or make her drowsy at the very least, something she couldn't have. She'd just have to rough it and let her body heal itself, even though she couldn't say the same for her memories.

Slowly, Kouji turned back to her, and tentatively added much more softly, ". . . And, uhm. . . it's good to see you're alright. . ."

However, Kouji had spoken too soon. Just as Beliamon made an attempt to sit back up, blunt, stiff pain spread up her back and sore joints, making her clench her teeth and grunt underneath her breath, "You don't say?" Beliamon remarked bittersweetly, closing her eyes to bide the further hammering in her head.

"You didn't exactly collapse in the most comfortable location," Kouji lamented as he indicated a small pile of rubble where they used to be standing, in the middle of a narrow, stone street.

"Ouch- that would explain the bruises," Beliamon observed sarcastically as she noted the mess of dull crumbled stone across the tight street. Kouji closed his eyes and nodded candidly. In that moment, Beliamon noticed that her prisoner's dark blue jacket was nowhere to be seen- he was clad only in the yellow shirt he wore underneath it that was slightly strained by a protruding paunch. Beliamon blinked as her head cleared for a moment, and immediately she found out where Kouji's jacket was, what her head had been resting on, and why she wasn't laying around in the rough pile of rubble where she collasped.

After a moment, Beliamon sighed to herself and attempted to rise to her feet once again. In a few moments, she managed to sit up and prop her back against one of the tall walls of the buildings. Just then, she realized Kouji was standing at her side and his hand outstretched toward her.

"Here," he mumbled frankly, blue eyes darting the other way as his cheeks turned a vivid color, saying nothing more- but he had gotten his point across. Though he didn't see it, there was gratitude that glinted only a little in her eyes that, even Beliamon had trouble entirely supressing it. Taking hold of his hand, Beliamon was standing up in no time, and in no time at all, their hands had seperated as well.

And then even more silence followed.

Both of them were having an extremely awkward day, to say the least.

There was no speaking or even moving for those few moments that seemed to last minutes- Beliamon wanted to recover a little more, and Kouji dare not fall astray if not for incurring the wrath of his captor, then simply for the fear of getting lost in a dead, empty city. Since the muffled voice of others in the distance, clattering steps, or even the wind were all absent from the area, it was true silence. And that eerie silence rang through the narrow streets- up until the point that Kouji spontaneously yawned, that is.

"Bored?" Beliamon muttered lowly.

Kouji shrugged, "No, not really," he said as he bent down and retrieved his bunched-up jacket from the sidewalk where Beliamon had been out cold earlier.

Beliamon let her head fall toward her shoulder, it had been a long while since they had left the Temple of Earth. Chances are, it could be getting late, but neither of them would be able to tell- the skies over Ayzahn Ra were an eternal gray.

Kouji noticed Beliamon had re-levitated her enormous backpack and started a modest pace down the narrow street again, calling back to him, "Come on, Kouji," but never looking back. With little contemplation, the ponytailed boy began to follow after her.

Soon, the two were out of the blocks containing the dormitory complex and were in a much more open area again.

I really wonder where we're headed, thought Kouji to himself as the twosome crossed a deserted plaza. Beliamon did say were weren't headed back toward the Temple of Earth. . . but, then again, that WAS a while ago. Kouji felt that both of them were starting to tire, and knew that they were going to have to take a longer, more peaceful rest sooner or later. But where?
13412211211211112211221212.title: Recovery

choices: The two enter the Temple of Light.
The two decide to explore around outside first.
134122112112111122112212122.content:
Kouji raised an eyebrow, glancing at his surroundings.

He wasn't familiar with Ayzahn Ra, but he could swear that this wasn't the way back towards the Temple of Earth.

"We're not going back to the Temple of Earth are we?" He asked suspiciously, coming to a stop.

Beliamon sighed and stopped as well, leaning up against the wall and letting her pack drop with an uncharacteristic thud. She felt unusually tired for some reason.

"No we're not." Beliamon turned to Kouji and opened her mouth as if to speak again, but bit her lip in hesistation.

Kouji only stared at her and she sighed again.

"I didn't tell you earlier, but I ran into Duskmon after you left the Belltower. I think it would be best if we relocated." Beliamon stated simply.

"Duskmon?" Kouji asked, blinking.

"Oh, that's right. I suppose you wouldn't have met him yet. Cherubimon does keep him cooped up fairly often. But anyway, Duskmon is a Dark Warrior, in fact he's your counterpart." Beliamon answered, heaving herself up and levitating her pack, and moving on leaving Kouji with the choice of following or being abandoned.

Of course he followed, Beliamon was able to note, by the second pair of sounding feet that soon joined her own.

"There's a Warrior of Darkness too?" Kouji asked, slightly surprised as he caught up with her.

"Yes. Cherubimon uses him for most of his...dirty work, I suppose." Beliamon answered, turning her head rapidly from left to right.

While it was true she wanted to relocate, had wanted to ever since she has felt Duskmon's presence within the Temple of Earth earlier, that wasn't all.

She had felt strange since entering the city, or actually, since she had abducted Kouji. She hadn't known why she had though to hide him away within the Temple of Earth, it being so close to Ayzahn Ra, or what was left of it.

It was as if Ayzahn Ra had been almost calling to her.

She had felt it when she had brought the unconscious Kouji to the Temple of Earth, when she had grocery shopped in the Belltower, and had grown even stronger when she encountered Taramon's flowers, still in bloom by their old dorm.

And it was STILL growing more powerful, even as she was walking down the streets right now.

The city, though she had no way to explain it, was...guiding her.

And that frightened her.

"Beliamon?" A voice questioned and Beliamon was jolted out of her reverie.

She turned to Kouji with an inquisative look.

Kouji sighed and gave his his captor a withered look.

"I was asking how you could have fended off Duskmon by yourself." He stated, for appearently the scond time.

Beliamon snorted as she and Kouji rounded a field, a dull green pasture coming into view as they neared the city limits.

"Whose said we fought? You seem to have forgotten, Kouji, that Duskmon adn I have the same employer. " Beliamon paused and added quietly. "Though neither of us chose to serve him."

Kouji stared at Beliamon for a minute before huffing and turning away.

Beliamon chuckled.

"You also forget my power. Now, I can match ANY of the Dark Warriors, even destroy them. I'd say Duskmon, and perhpas Mercurymon would only stand a chance against me. And thats if I don't digivolve to my Ultimate form." Beliamon said passionately, and Kouji looked at her curiously.

"What do you mean how?" He asked.

"What?"

"You said now. Almost like you fought them before and lost."

"Oh...hehe. Of course not. I just meant that...I used to be very weak." Beliamon said nervously, waving her hand.

"Suuuure." Kouji said dryly, and sighing, turned his attention forward again. "So..we're headed to that field up there?"

Beliamon looked towards the field herself and gulped. She was being pullled toward it, that much she knew, and as they got closer she began to recognize it.

"That field is where the Temple of Light used to stand." She said sadly, nothing that now, only rubble littered the pasture, sometimes piled in high heaps.

"The Temple of Light?" Kouji asked from beside her.

"Yes, it was said to be one of the most beautiful temples." Beliamon said and closed her eyes as memories of crystal buildings accented with creamy white marble and shimmering opal rose within her mind. "It used to be beaitiful, to watch the sun rising over the Temple of Light, the light catching on it's crystal turrets."

Kouji turned his attention back to the field as his imagination tried to picture what the Temple used to look like.

After a while, as the duo grew closer to the field, the buildings, or what remained of them, became clearer.

Giant piles of dirty white stone, marble and opal dirtied from destruction and fire, was apparent as was slivers of dirty crystal, now just dull glass, in even bigger assortments.

The only structure still partly whole was a giant set of dirty marble steps leading up to a rather large ruined building.

"That used to be the Great Hall of the Temple." Beliamon noted as they both stared at it's remains. "Many classes were held here. It was also a kind of an Administration building and held the offices of the Headmaster."

Suddenly, Beliamon felt a pain in her chest, and with a cry collapsed to the ground, writhing in pain.

Kouji was immediately beside her and gasp at what he saw.

Just below Beliamon'n neck, shining through the black fabric of her dress, was the symbol of Light.

With a swift motion, the light intensified, as did Beliamon's shouting, and the light then shot out from her chest, making its way quickly up the steps, before pasuing just over the rubble of the Great Hall.

A flash of light.

Beliamon gasped, deeply inhaling air for a moment as the pain finally left her.

"What...in the world....?" She gasped, grabbing onto Kouji's shoulder for support.

Kouji wasn't looking at her though. He was staring out to where the light had flashed, a look of awe on his face.

Curious, Beliamon followed it, and ofr the second- or maybe third- time that day her heart stopped.

Where there had once been rubble, there now stood a partially complete Great Hall.

The light that had shot out from her, no doubt from Kouji's digivice she noted to herself, had apparently removed a veiling spell cast upon the Great Hall to persaude passerby it had been destroyed, though it had been, at least to some extent.

The marble steps were now restored to a somewhat ivory state and now led up to an actual building. The building itself was made of an opaque crystal with traces of opal running here and there throughout it. The right side of the building, however, seemed to be completely destroyed, and even the rest appeared to be slightly damged.

Most amazing however, was that from the center of the Great Hall, a turret emerged and thrust into the sky. It was of a seethrough crystal, and steps of marble wove their way around the tower to the top, which was crowned by a large chunk of hollow crystal.

And amazingly, it was undamaged.

"The...the Great Hall..." Beliamon managed to choke out. "If some of the outside has survived, then the inside must surely be functional!

Kouji turned to her with a smirk.

"So can we stay here then?"
134122112112111122112212122.title: The Temple of Light

choices: Meanwhile, while Beliamon was searching for a kitchen of some sort. . .
Later, when Beliamon woke Kouji up. . .
1341221121121111221122121221.content:
The pearly doors burst open and light spread into the entryway of the Great Hall for the first time in eons.

The twosome found themselves in a medium sized chamber, one which Kouji found comparable to the size of a typical classroom, with a good exception being the heightened roof which stood at least ten feet above his head. The floor was a milky colored marble that shined and reflected the light that flooded into the room.

Scanning the room with quickly darting eyes, on the wall opposite them stood an even greater double door crafted of a material that resembled ivory; each was adorned with a sizable ruby ring to help open the massive door. The large doorway was flanked by a set of pilars and holsters magically bolted to the wall that at one time may have contained some kind of torch. Also, two, similar tall doorways stood on the left and right walls, each guarded by a pair of wooden benches padded with relaxing looking faded red pillows.

Kouji noticed that although the place may have had a lot of fancy details, strangely, he felt more comfortable and at ease. . . Maybe that was because he was the Warrior of Light, after all. . . and also because he had a nice bench right in front of him to lay back in, with a comfy looking pillow nonetheless!

And so, after a moment's of hesitation, Kouji promptly fell back into the soft cushions of the closest bench, and kicked up his legs, "So this is where we're going to be staying for the. . . night, I guess?" he shrugged as he upturned his gaze towards the lacking, constant nothingness gray of the sky he could still see out the door.

"I think so, if that's what you want to call it," Beliamon nodded, "I thought it would make a nice change from the Temple of Earth- oh," Beliamon blushed before breaking out in a grin, and rubbing the back of her head, "Erm, honestly, I've never been here before myself."

One of Kouji's eyebrows shot up in astoundment, "What do you mean, you've never been here before?"

Beliamon shook her head, "Just because I lived in the city for a while doesn't mean that I got accepted to learn or study magic in one of its ten most prestigious temples."

"Oh," Kouji said blandly, "But hold on- how come you knew so much about the layout of the Great Hall?" he questioned.

"Word of mouth?" Beliamon suggested, "Many, if not all, of students frequented out of the Temple dormitories and mingled in the city. They were everywhere; so it really wasn't out of the blue to meet one on the streets or listen to them at a restaurant or inn."

"Oh," Kouji nodded, defeated again, as he leaned back into the soft bench. Just as he started to lean back further and maybe try to take a small rest, Beliamon had already approached the double doors opposite him, made a strange flicker with her arm across the door, and was attempting entry. Quickly, Kouji jumped to his feet and went to join her in pushing the heavy doors aside.

The double doors parted with a loud creak, revealing what could possibly be the largest room either of them had even seen. The floor was also made of the white colored marble, except this time, it was highly polished, and the two of them could see their own glossy reflections below them, and it expanded onward and onward until it hit the distant wall, seemingly far, far away. Also seemingly distant away was the ceiling, which made Kouji's eyes widen when he peered upward and saw the almost limitless ceiling with all the arches and buttresses held above him. The vast opaque crystal walls of the room were also lined with faded banners.

The two observed that four or five long banquet tables of a light colored wood with long rows of benches on either side were set up across the ballroom sized chamber, and had probably been set up like that for a long, long time.

After a brief moment of silent awe, Kouji remarked, "

"Are you kidding me?" Beliamon exclaimed, her cry echoing throughout the immense room, making Kouji jump and his belly bobble slightly, "If climbing up a set of stairs, front and center, and getting past a pair of doors was all it was to it, I would have easily snuck into here ages ago. . . uhm," she blushed as her quicky commentary echoed excitedly across the room.

"But yeah, believe it or not, Kouji, this used to be much, much bigger," Beliamon nodded solemnly, "Obviously much of the Temple has been destroyed. . . I remember there used to be some kind of crystal wall around the campus, so that the staircase we walked up a while ago would be in the middle of a courtyard. I also remember seeing several more buildings aside from the Great Hall reflecting the light every morning. . ." Beliamon sighed as she remembered that one morning, where she had decided to camp outside the dorms for that special day off. . .

She had fallen asleep around the wooded height of the meadow, and when she woke up that morning, there it was; a vibrant pink sky with thick, smoky clouds dragging across the horizon, remnants of the night. But most radiant of all was the Temple of Light in the distance, reflecting the light in wonderful, shimmering flashes of a multitude of color and intensity.

Suddenly, a deep, grumbling sound interrupted her reminiscing, and leading her mood to change.

Slowly, Beliamon's eyes deviously rolled over to look at a pallid looking Kouji, whose own eyes darted away in hopes of avoiding her attention.

"Oh, that's right," Beliamon said, a smirk coming to her lips, "You haven't had anything at all to eat today, have you? Why didn't you remind me?" she laughed, "After all that excercise. . . "

Kouji's only response to this was a stony glare.

"I did stock up on ingredients today, so how could I forget?" she nodded, indicating her backpack, "So I guess you're in for a treat then, Kouji," she cackled as she gave his bulging paunch a healthy poke, making the ponytailed boy blanch.

"No, really, I'm fine!" he protested flailing his hands, his face now breaking into a deep blush, as he saw Beliamon silently head off to the entryway to hunt out a kitchen, or, at least somewhere where she could cook or concoct something for him to eat.

Kouji sighed for what had to be the umpteeth time that day as he exited the humongous room.

Leaving the door to the Great Hall ajar, Kouji shook his head before collapsing onto the bench that he had sat down in before; he was in for a nice, refreshing, well-deserved rest.

Although, he knew it in his heart that Beliamon probably needed it much, much more than he did.
1341221121121111221122121221.title: Entering the Great Hall

13412211211211112211221212211.content:
Cerfeully, Beliamon opened yet another of the doors that lined this part of the Temple of Light. Poking her head in slowly, so as she didn't rush in to a room that could be in wreckage or collapse, she saw that it was a small parlor, still mostly intact, where professors could relax or work on tomorrow's lessons after a busy day of teaching.

Giving the room only a few more seconds of inspection, Beliamon sighed and closed the door behind her, turning her attention to the twenty some doors they had left.

'And then there's the fact that some rooms may have others branching off of them.' Beliamon noted to herself, and continued her trek, this time choosing a door on the left side of the hallway.

To tell the truth, she was getting just a bit...creeped out. For being part of the Temple of Light, the part she had explored thus far was terribly dim. She could only imagine how it would be at night.

Peeking her head in again for this room, she found it to be a small lab, the kind that were only reserved to the professors for experiments they believed were either to dangerous or too complicated to be taught or observed to even the brightest students of the Temple.

Beliamon closed the door and grumbled to herself as she made her way to the next door in the long line she needed to expect.

This was becoming far too tedious. She had hoped to have a good meal in Kouji's belly, hopefully before it became completely dark outside, in order to replace all of the calories he'd lost during the day and then some.

Otherwise, he would start shrinking again. And that was a no-no in every possible way.

Hoping that this door would at least give her some sort of clue as to where the kitchen would be located, she opened it to find a classroom this time.

Beliamon stared into the room for a few moments, her eye twitching, before she slammed the door in frustation.

She was surprised, however, that such a force upon the door caused it to fly off of its hinges and hit the floor with a resounding thud, dust scattering everywhere.

Trying to think, she crossed her arms.

'If I was a kitchen, now where would I be?' She asked herself. 'Well, the kitchen would most likely be adjacent to the cafeteria, and I imagine the cafeteria wouldn't be behind one of these little doors. It would probably be in a part of the building that was easily accesible and...maybe it had big doors?'

Beliamon scanned the halway to test her theory and was excited when she found a large set of doors at the very end of the hallway. She guessed it was also accessible from the outside, as it appeared to be on the end of this hallway and...well, it had big doors.

Rather than walking, a habit she had adapted from being with Kiouji, she supposed, she levitated herself and moved down the hallway and a fairly quick speed, reaching the doors in just a few seconds.

Heaving the large set of doors, she hopefully looked inside and was ecstatic to find that it was indeed the cafeteria.

The cafeteria itself was rather large, scattered with either crystal or marble tables, many of which were broken though a few still stood in usuable if worn condition. The ceiling itself was mostly a grand skylight, with a few crystal chandeliers hanging in place to provide light during the evening.

Remonding herself that the cafeteria was not her actual goal, she spied the room to find any signs of a kitchen door, and found them not too far away from where she stood, on the left side of the room.

Entering hastily, Beliamon gasped at the sight.

The kitchens were all she had hoped for and more. The room appeared to be in practically perfect condition, with spotless countertops and silver ranges and sinks lining both sides of the wall. Pans and pots of all sizes hung from the ceiling, small and large enough to make anything from a single serving of mashed potatoes to the largest pot roast anyone had ever seen.

There were also many cabinets for storage lining the rooms and what looked like a pantry further back in the room, and upon inspection and to Beliamon's delight, both were found to still be partially stocked.

Chuckling, Beliamon stopped in front of a range, and smirked.

She was definately going to have fun with this...

***

Wiping the sweat from her brow away with a cloth, Beliamon admired her work.

She had made quite a feast, even if she did say so herself.

For the entree, she had made peppered steak, tenderized fully and seasoned with the best spices she had found in the pantrym along with grilled salmon, vut into bite sized pieces and also seasoned with spices.

For side dishes, she had prepared a small but generous mound of garlic mashed potatoes, also seasoned with freshly ground pepper, in addition to a small loaf of bread, freshly made and coming with various spreads and jams she had placed on the tray with the bread for Kouji to choose from.

And lastly, for dessert, Beliamon had prepared something of a chocolate moose. Chocolate as well as vanilla ice cream layered with hot fudge, crumbs of chocolate cookies, pieces of broken fudge, and a few pieces of caramel littered her and there throughout the chocolate masterpiece. It was also quite large, one of the reason why Beliamon had made the other portions of Kouji's meal smaller than usual.

She just hoped Kouji had a sweet tooth.

Setting her dessert and the rest of Kouji's meal on a cart she had found, as well as several drinks she had chosen; Apple cider, creamy whole milk, and severl varieties of juics and soft drinks, Beliamon then strained to levitate the cart as well as herself, and began making her way back to Kouji at a slower speed than she had arrived, but faster than it would have been if she had walked.

Leaving the kitchen behind her and then quickly moving beyond the cafeteria and coming back to the hallway, all the the time being careful not to drop any part of her feast, she soon arrived back to Kouji, who to her happiness, was almost asleep.

The body tended to store more fat when it was sleepy.

Of course, as soon as Kouji caught sight of the feast Beliamon had prepared, he balked and looked at her as if she was insane.

She returned his look with a cheshire grin of her own. Perhpas she was insane.

"I hope you're hungry, Kouji darling, I worked hard on this meal." Beliamon said jovially, before eying the almost plump boy. "And that means you had better eat it all."

"You're crazy if you think I can eat all that." Kouji replied, but nonetheless sitting up and taking the first few bits of the peppered steak and the grilled salmon.

Beliamon shrugged and bent down to retrieve ther beverages she had brought with her.

"You may surprise yourself. You havn't eaten all day and you've been walking." She replied, adding a bit more in her mind to herself.

'Take that and the fact that, while its only been minor so far, your body has grown slightly accustomed to doing nothing all day and then eating.' She noted with a secret smirk.

"What to drink? I've got apple cider, milk, soft drinks, orange, apple, and grape juice..." Beliamon listed the beverages.

"You sure brought a lot." Kouji told her as he shoveled a spoonfull of mashed potatoes into his mouth.

Again Beliamon shrugged, and deciding for Kouji, poured him a large tankard of milk.

"We can actually keep these drinks here in their jugs and they won't begin to spoil. Its when they leave their jugs, magically enchanted, that they begin to spoil, so as long as we leave them in their containers, they won't spoil!" Beliamon excplained to Kouji happily. "I can probably bring you some snack foods with the same effect tomorrow.

Kouji's response was a roll of his eyes, but he continued eating, this time a piece of bread covered in blackberry jam.

"And while we're here we have the whole building to explore, or at least what's left it." Beliamon noted as she turned her gaze off towards the parts of the Temple she had not yet explored.

"Hmph. Well what do you expect to find?" Kouji asked offhand as he tore into more of the grilled salmon.

Beliamon, however, didn't answer. She was still staring off into the unexplored regions of the Great Hall, a strange look in her eyes.

Kouji shrugged Beliamon's lack of an answer, contributing it to one of her odd moods or...or perhaps she hadn't yet fully healed. Either way, he continued eating his meal, for the first time, not thinking what it would do to his waistline, though he undoubtedly would later.

'What am I going to do..?' Beliamon thought to herself, amidst the jumble of thoughts plagueing her mind. Sighing deeply, she banished the thoughts from her mind.

It really didn't matter. No matter what path she took now, it would end ugly. All she could do now was to try and get through this with as little pain as possible...
13412211211211112211221212211.title: The First Meal in the Temple of Light.

134122112112111122112212122111.content:
Beliamon tread down a lonely and dimly lit passage in the Temple of Light, once more going it solo.

Kouji had chose to stay behind, claiming he wanted some time to himself. Looking back, Beliamon saw Kouji did have a point with his excuse. . . both of them could probably benefit from some more time alone. However, Beliamon suspected that Kouji would resume his nap on the bench, and this time sleep soundly.

Beliamon could tell that Kouji was truly tired just by the look on his face; and if he was going get some sleep, she'd certainly have to leave the area. It wouldn't be likely for Kouji just to allow himself to comfortably take forty winks in the midst of her presence. And after that abundant meal Beliamon had served up for him, she had little doubt in her mind that Kouji would have no trouble at all getting to slumberland, given he was by himself.

Continuing her ventures down the unexplored corridors of the vast and dilapidated Temple of Light, Beliamon peered ahead and saw that the narrow confines of the hallway would soon open up.

As she emerged from the shadowy hallway, Beliamon entered what seemed to be a deserted terrace. However, parts of the smooth moonlike marble had crumbled away, and only half of it seemed walkable. An intact bench without a back made of a similar marble stood on the firm marble ground, next to a balustrate on the edge.

And no there was no sky.

***

The sky was clear and flushed a bright cerulean blue while white, fluffy clouds drifted their way across the open.

"He DIDN'T come!" cheered an overly delighted voice.

"Don't get your hopes up just yet," sighed a second speaker flatly, "Were you looking out the entire time? Maybe he passed by quickly while you were daydreaming or something."

Leiamon recoiled before cracking a sheepish, twitchy smirk, "No way... besides, if Yoimon bolted the street, who do you think would be the first to notice?"

Taramon didn't glance back as she continued watering her flowers, "Leiamon, I still don't think this is a good idea."

"Aw, come on, Tara," Leiamon sighed, aimlessly straddling the nearby desk chair, "We've gone over it before. . . True, it may have taken me a while to come up with it in the first place, but I'm sure it'll all work out just fine!"

Taramon spun around and shot a skeptical eyebrow up at her friend, "Alright, Lei- you have one last chance to convince me to help you with this. Explain how this is going to work one more time for me."

Leiamon folded her arms over the back of the chair and massaged her forehead, "Okay, first, we wait until Yoimon accidentally sleeps in, gets lost, or for whatever other reason- basically, he has to end up showing late for chores-"

Taramon nodded for Leiamon to continue, "So, as you know, chores are rotated continually and normally assigned by dorms; that is, you, me, and everyone else in the Blueroof Dorms will be assigned and divided up among other Blueroof boarders. The same goes for the Redroofs- so normally, no matter what, Yoimon would only be working with other Redroof lodgers.

But then I remembered that if you show up late for your chores, you still have to report to work in the afternoon, except the work load's supposed to be a lot more than the morning chores. But the interesting thing is the workers for the afternoon chores are lumped into one big group, no matter which dorm you stay at. I think that's because pretty much everyone gets their work done in the morning, so the numbers for each dorm are much smaller in the afternoon. I guess it's so much easier to divide up a larger number for the afternoon tasks. . ."

"Basically. . ." Taramon summed up, shaking her head, "What you're saying is if Yoimon slept in today, we should show up late, report in for afternoon chores, and do double the work. . . just so then there might be the small chance that we'd end up working with Yoimon, one out of hundreds of Digimon?"

Leiamon nodded, "Well, there's always a glimmer of hope, right, Tara?"

There was a long silence before Leiamon added with a diminished voice, "So, what do you say, Tara?"

Taramon cast a glance that lasted a little too long at the door, "You know, Lei," she started, "I know you put a lot of thought into this, but. . ." she stopped, "Well, you know, there's a lot of things that can go wrong with this," she stated, changing directions, as she brushed a strand of her blue hair aside with a finger, .

"Yeah, what?" Leiamon implored.

"Well, for starters, Yoimon could have decided to jog a different route to work this morning," Taramon explained, "And like I said before, even if all these conditions are met, the actual chances of getting to work with him are very small ones."

Leiamon stared back blankly, "Oh yeah. . ." she blushed, "But Tara, I've been waiting days and days for even a sign that Yoimon's going to turn up late; besides, he runs down this way every time. Besides, this is the only way I'll ever get to work with Yoimon. I mean, yeah, the chances might not be great, but if it happens- that could be a great opportunity. This could be it. . ." she sighed passionately, before clenching her fists and snapping, "Besides, what do we have to lose, anyway?"

"My perfect attendance record, for one," Taramon joked, but her face softened as she peered back at her friend, "Listen, Lei, I think that you're right this time, if you really like Yoimon, you should get a chance to know him; you've definitely got to make a move at him before it's too late. I suppose two or three tardy days and a little extra work wouldn't hurt you or me."

"Thanks, Tara," Leimon smiled back.

* * *

Leiamon gasped as her head emerged from a fairly large crowd of young Digimon aspirants. Bewildered, she staggered away from the pile congregating around the large bulletin slate fixed on an easel that contained the work schedule for the afternoon.

"Well?" Taramon asked, "Are our names even on the list?"

Leiamon took a deep breath and shrugged, much to Taramon's vexation, "There were a lot of names; so I'm guessing the names of everyone that didn't show this morning were just cast down here as well."

"I hope you're right," Taramon nodded, "I'm also supposing the actual table is different than the morning version."

"Well, yeah," said Leiamon, "But from what I hear, today's there's a really light work load from the norm- only three work periods."

"Wow, that's only one more than from what we typically have," Taramon said, a little surprised.

"I bet Yoimon couldn't have picked a better day to sleep in," Leiamon laughed, causing Taramon to chuckle in agreement.

Within a few moments, the crowd had dissolved and thinned up as a few took off to their respective work stations, although quite a few chose to lounge about until hours started. Leiamon and Taramon both approached the board to examine it more closely.

With butterflies soaring in her stomach, Leiamon anxiously scanned the lines and columns of the chart. Tension began to well up with her, as this was the moment of truth, determining whether or not her plan would be a waste. Like Taramon had said, after all, it was a very, very small chance. . . and the chart was quite big, well over hundreds of names. . .

Just then, Taramon clapped a hand on her shoulder, "Don't worry about it, Lei. I'm sure he'll be here," she assured her, "And even if you don't get chores with him, we'll know where to look for him after we're done."

Leiamon nodded several times over, took a nervous gulp, "Thanks, Tara," she sighed, and a small, comforted smile creeping up her lips. Then, very slowly, her eyes scrolled over to the bottom of the list.

. . .

'Yoimon'

It shot out toward her eyes like a glint of gold in a dust field.

"It said, 'Yoimon!' Leiamon grinned, "That means he's here."

Taramon gave Leiamon a warm smile, before saying, "It also says we have kitchen duty together first," as she traced her fingers across both their names.

"Hold on. . ." Leiamon's eyes widened, the whites huge and her pupils standing small in the center. Her mouth began to fall agape, "Did you just tell me. . . we have kitchen duty first?"

Taramon checked over her reading once again, just to be sure, "Yeah, at least, it says so right here."

"But that's. . ." Leiamon whispered in a hoarse yet tremendously excited voice, "That's what. . . what. . ."

All in an instant, Leiamon had let out a cry of rejoice, and was springing off her feet.

"Yes! Yes! Yes!" she cheered enthusiastically, thrusting a fist into the air with every 'yes' she could muster.

Immediately understanding, and perhaps even interpretting the screams of bliss, Taramon began to laugh, overjoyed that all had worked out fine.

Just as soon as Leiamon and her revelry started to calm down, Taramon broke out into a chuckle again as she ran across the schedule again, "Well, Leiamon, Yoimon really DID pick the right day to sleep in. Look what he has after kitchen duty," she suggested.

Leiamon was speechless and blankeyeed for a few more moments after she had read the next grid of both of their schedules, "And then we both have dishwashing... together," she giggled softly, her eyes dancing.

"And apparently just the two of you alone- or at least, of that we know of," Taramon put in, smirking, "During second block, I have to scrub the floors clean in some bookkeeping building."

"But look," Leiamon put in, "We both get to wash sheets together during the last block."

"Oh," Taramon snickered, "And will Yoimon be there too?" she teased.

"Very funny," Leiamon stated blandly, "But, no, it doesn't look like he has chores with me during the last block."

"Well, Lei," Taramon said as the two headed off for their first chore, "It looks like things are going very, very well for you so far. . ."

* * *

It was a well known fact, or at least a well known fact to Taramon, that Leiamon had some interest in cooking. With the little amount of cash she could hold on to, Leiamon was able to gather up some ingredients to scrounge up a meal for herself and Taramon every now and again, cooking it all up on a small, makeshift magic fire. Even though every a warm and well-prepared meal was free, available, and waiting to be eaten by all boarders every morning, night, and afternoon, Taramon still enjoyed trying Leiamon's homemade dishes whenever she made them. . . even if she was still learning and her skills still needed refinement every now and then.

"I wonder what we'll end up making for kitchen duty," Leiamon pondered. Taramon shrugged honestly as the two crossed another street.

Taramon seemed to know where their assignment station was located, and the pair of friends arrived inside a large but crowded scullery. The walls seemed to be lined with polished countertops, large washbasin sinks here and there, and of course, racks hanging high above lined with pots and pans, and large bins and cabinets storing common ingredients. There were even a few doors leading to the front, a double door to the main kitchen and a few doors leading to what could only be pantries fully stocked with a variety of food and myriad of ingredients.

A huge number aspiring students were present, most of them were all sitting at two, long, battered, wooden tables that had been set up for them.

Even so, it was a huge room, and Yoimon could be anywhere.

"Do you see Yoimon?" Taramon asked her friend, competing with the collective racket of the small talk of several young Digimon.

"Hold on," Leiamon urged as she quickly darted her eyes across the room, rapidly over the head of everyone. She shook her head, "Not yet. He just has to be in here somewhere," she stated.

"I think this was the only place holding kitchen duty today," Taramon stated as she nodded, also looking over a few faces.

Just then the double doors burst open with a clatter, silencing most of the conversation.

"Please be seated," sounded a bellowing voice issuing from that direction. Immediately, Leiamon and Taramon took the closest seat they could find.

In stepped a businesslike looking Ogremon wearing horn-rimmed glasses with a white apron strapped about him. One of his long, green arms was wrapped around an enormous, steel pot almost the size of Leiamon, while the other grasped the ends of an equally large, burlap sack. It only took him a moment to reach the front of the room, and he placed the pot down in between the two tables, a peal of water licking up from it as it hit the ground.

As the sack also fell to the ground, the Ogremon retrieved a small, white slip of paper, "Today you will peel potatoes," he read frankly from the sheet, receiving a few rolling eyes and sighs, "Each Digimon will start off with five potatoes. Each Digimon will get a towel. Each Digimon will peel potatoes with a potato peeler," the Ogremon read off, and continued to blandly describe the procedure on how exactly to peel a potato to his audience of roughly a hundred young Digimon.

"Do not eat the potatoes. And, as always, with any chore, do not use magic," he concluded before folding up the sheet and passing out the bins with the peelers to the tables.

Leiamon sighed before her work after she returned with five potatoes from the sack, "I was hoping we'd actually get to make something..." she remarked and started to idly peel away, looking around for any hide or hair of Yoimon among all the turned backs.

Taramon shrugged, pushing a lock of her blue hair aside, "It figures that we have to do the preparation work for the chefs."

One by one, the five potatoes were peeled, Leiamon and Taramon walked up the aisle, dumped them into the pot, and got five more.

Peering around on her way back, Leiamon could still only see the backs of unfamiliar heads.

And so, the process was continued again and again, time and time again. As time passed, the potato skins had formed taller and taller heaps on the expanse of the towels that were presented to each worker.

After a while, the Ogremon had left for a few moments. Shortly after his departure, conversation flared and a few Digimon had gotten up to sit closer to their friends.

Leiamon had just finished her fifth potato and bundled them all up in her arms, "I'll be right back," she told Taramon as she got up to dump the potatoes into the pot, get some more, and possibly scope out Yoimon.

Leiamon turned around, looking over the backs of those seated at the table across from where she was sitting to see those facing them, trying to find Yoimon. This was really frustrating her. She had already secretly searched the row she was sitting at and the row across from her at her own table on her trips to and from the potato pot to no avail. . . Where could he be?

Leiamon released her bundle of shaven potatoes into the deep waters of the big kettle and turned her glance back to her own table, slightly staggering to the side so she could get a closer look at the faces.

Suddenly, a thought flashed into her mind.

The answer was just under her nose! What if she had totally missed Yoimon because she was so intent on examining everyone who was seated, and he just had simply gotten up out of his seat to deposit his potatoes?

Lost in her thoughts, Leiamon didn't know just how right she was until it was too late.

With a loud smack, Leiamon in her absent-minded state had just crashed and fallen right into...
134122112112111122112212122111.title: Recollecting on the Balcony

choices: Someone new had entered the room.
1341221121121111221122121221111.content:
A squawk followed by several thumpings noises pulled Taramon's attnetion away from peeling her potatoes to the front of the room, near the potato pot.

Taramon began to sweat a little as she stood up to get a better view.

'Lei just went over there...I hope she didn't fall into the pot..' She thought as she quickly got up and began walking over to said pot to rescue her friends from whatever predickament she had gotten herself into this time.

Doing her best to weave through the mass of digimon that had erupted, she managed to peek through several groups to try and spy her friend.

And almost tripped in the process.

Lei was standing over someone, obviously Yoimon, looking like a criminal caught at the scen of the crime.

Taramon's eyebrow ticked but she smiled nonetheless as she redoubled her effort to reach her friend.

Only Leiamon could pull off such a performance with incredible odds against her and then manage to mess up in the final act.


**

Leiamon was rooted to the spot, completley mortified.

'Well....I was right at least.' She told herself in consolation.

Yoimon had indeed been bringing his potatoes up to the pot at about the same times as she had been.

Unofrtunately, in her zeal to locate him she had kind of...knocked him over.

"I-I am SO sorry..." Leiamon squeeked, her face crimson. She then bent down and tried to gather up Yoimon's peeled potatoes, which had taken a tumble with him.

Reaching for one that had rolled under part of a table, her blush increased. She could hear stifled laughter all throughout the room.

"Oh...heh...don't worrry about it.." Yoimon siad a bit dizzily as he sat up from his place on the floor. Focusing on Leiamon, he flashed her a good-natured grin.

"For being so small you sure do pack a punch!" Yoimon said with a chuckle before a slightly panicked look came to his face. "Not that you're like puny or anything!"

Leiamon giggled and smiled to herself at what she hoped had been a compliment. Shyly, she allowed herself a glance of him.

**

"Excuse me." Taramon mewled as she struggled to get to the front of the room.

Unlike herself and Leiamon, most of their workmates had opted to talk, and the aisles were now sprawled with people and limbs who had gotten up to talk or had moved into a more comfortable position while their supervisor was away.

Needless to say, she was having a bit of a hard time. Unlike Lei, she had to worry about getting her dress snagged or dirty. It was also much harder to walk. Not to mention she was wearing heels.

"Outta the way, Grandma."

Taramon barely had time to register the voice before she was shoved into a mass of people. Ignoring the sounds of protest of the people she had been shived into, and trying to control her temper, she turned towards the voice of her attacker, now openly laughing.

"Wow, with all those ruffles I though you would be more graceful." The voice remarked sarcastically.

Now certain of where - or who - the voice was coming from, Taramon frowned in distaste.

"You were even more black than my friend. But at least she's clean." Taramon said with a sniff before rolling her eyes at her attacker in a condescending way. "But I suppose some creatures don't have the intelligence to know what soap is. I was wondering where that stench was coming from, so know I know at least."

Taramon was delighted with herself when she heard a growl and fully turned to glare upon her attacker.

Taller than here by almost one and a half heads, Taramon figured him to be a little taller than Yoimon, and like she said, he wore black like Leiamon.

However, instead of looking like a mage digimon specializing in dark magic, he looked similar to a back alley gangster.

He was wearing black boots and black jeans and also a black shirt and a small black jacket over his shirt. Everything was black, including his hair, which was tied back into a short ponytail, with the exception of a simple silver necklace he was wearing, a small silver earringfixed to one ear, and his belt- which was actually a silver chain.

"You have a problem with me, Granny?" He asked,annoyed.

Taramon eyebrow twitched.

"I should be the one asking you that! You all but shoved me into those nice digimon! And my name is not Granny!"

"Yeah, after hearing you talk for a bit, you sound more like a princess than a grandma." He said, smirking. "Nice talkin'to ya, but I have to go help my friend. Some blonde klutz completly bulldozed him a second ago."

Taramon's rage stopped a moment when he mentioned who she knew to be Lei, but quicklly recovered by takking hold of a firm grip on her attacker's necklace.

After making a strangled noise, he turned on her, a slightly startled look in his eyes.

"Uh uh uh..you're not getting away from me so easily." Taramon taunted. "And for your infomration, that 'klutz' is my friend."

Yanking away Taramon's hand from his necklace and this time looked at her if she was insane.

"So you're a friend of Yoimon's then." Taramon stated and sighed. "How in the world would he get to know a lowlife like you?"

"The name's Raomon, Princess!" Taramon's attacker, now known as Raomon growled. "And I can say the same for you. That blonde may be a klutz but I don't know how anyone could become friends with a snob like you."

"Snob?!"

"Yes, snob."

"Well at least I bathe!"

"Going back to syaing I stink again, huh? You must be running out of comebacks!"

"You are intolerable! You..you hooligan!"

"Again you prove that you're a grandma. Who says 'hooligan'?

"Argh!"

Taramon, massaged her temples, trying to calm herself, but was having trouble doing so. Friend of Yoimon or not, this guy was unbearable.

"Be careful Granny; you might overheat you brain." He taunted again.

Taramon snapped.

Taking a deep breath, she offered Raomon one of her brightest smiles.

"You're right." She said placidly beforing eying him evilly, her smile transforming into a smirk.

"Let me cool yours off too!"



**

He looked even better close up.

His face, framed by brown, innocent eyes which were currently sparkling with amusement and a shock of brown hair, falling over a red hairband just short of said eyes, was alit with laughter.

Getting up and dusting himself off, she noted his clothes, which only accentuated his features further: Wearing some faded jeans and white sneakers, as well as a sleeveless blue top shat displayed his slighlty muscled arms, he really did look like the runner she had imagined him to be.

Deep within her own musings, she had almost missed the hand he was offering her. Taking it and letting Yoimon pull her up from the floor to a standing position she smiled at him.

"Um...thank you." She said awkwardly. "I really am sorry about before. And your potatoes, they're dirty. What will Professor Ogremon or whatever he is say?"

Yoimon was about to reply, but zoned out suddenly, his attention moving to something behind Leiamon. Turning quickly, she nearly fell over again with surprise.

"Take this you jerk!" A shourt was heard throughout the room and everyone's attention, which had gradually radiated away from Yoimon and Leiamon came full circle to who Leiamon could scarcely believe was Taramon and the poor guy she just drenched with a jet of water.

"Oh...my..." Leiamon was floored for a few seconds before reality came rushing back to her along with the laughter of their workmates at the scene! "Taramon!"

"Rao?...Oh!" Yoimon asked outloud from beside her and began to jog over to where Taramon and the other digimon before he realized he was still holding his potatoes and quickly running back and depositing them into the pot, dirty or not.

He then rejoined Leiamon and the two made their way over to their friends; Taramon victorious, with her hands on her hips and smiling pleasantly at who Leiamon guessed was Raomon, who was spluterring curses right and left and lokking at Taramon incredulously.

Squuezing their way into the circle that had formed around their pair, Leiamon and Yoimon regarded their friends with varied approaches.

"Taramon..Why? Um, How? When maybe..?" Leiamon stumbled through her words. Yoimon, however, greeted his friend with more gusto.

"Wow. She completely showed you Rao. Or should I say showered?" Yoimon said with a chessy grin, laughing at his own joke, "I guess you're not as bad as you think you are."

"Hmph." Raomon responded, still tryinh to shake some of the water off. "Now I can add Witch to my list of titles."

Leiamon glanced at her friend nervously, but was surprised to see Taramon only giving him a goofy smile as she held up the V for Victory sign with her right hand.

"Yeah, keep talking. I've won the round today, so whatever." She replied victoriously.

"We were competing?"

"Yes, we were."

"Since when!?"

"Rao, don't be a sore loser."

"And you! I thought she knocked you over? Shouldn't you be out cold?"

"Don't talk to her like that!"

"Who says I can't?!"

"Me!"

Leiamon sighed to herself and stepped back from all of the bickering for a moment.

Everything had worked out well....

Leiamon nearly fell down, suddenly remembering she hadn't told Yoimon her name.

Hesitantly, she tapped him on the shoulder, ulling him out of the bickering meatch Taramon and Raomon were having.

He looked at her questioningly and she blushed, looking down at the floor.

"By the way...I'm Leiamon." She said softly.

Yoimon blinked and then broke out into a wide grin.

"Oh, yeah! I'm Yoimon. Kinda weird, we forgot to tell each other our names." He said, scratching the back of his head and offering her another smile.

Leiamon giggled.

'Yes...now, everything is on the right track..' Leiamon thought to herself as she and Yoi turned their attnetion back to theri friend' argument.

Then suddenly the doors to the room opened again.

'Okay...maybe not...' Leiamon thought to herself once again and turned to see that..
