choices: Block Two starts with Leiamon and Yoimon dishwashing
Block Two starts with Tara and Rao scrubbing floors at the bookkeeping building
13412211211211112211221212211111.content:
The doors burst open with a bang. With that noise, the workmates scattered about the room in a mad dash back to their seats.

Taking that as a cue, Raomon shot one last sneer out at Taramon who returned him with an intimidating glare of contempt that made both their hairs stands on end. The two then scowled in unison at each other before both tramping back to their seats at exactly the same time.

Taking that as a cue, Yoimon started to make a move toward the once elusive location of his seat- but he turned and stopped suddenly, and his warm eyes were now on Leiamon.

Taking that cue, Leiamon briefly nodded and strided forward with him.

"Hold on," stammered the Ogremon, reentering the large chamber. Pushing his thick spectacles back up, his vision focused and sharpened, and what soon came to his eyes did not impress, but then again...

Shaking his gray mane of hair, the great green Digimon took a heaving sigh. So they decided to lax off while he was gone. It wasn't really anything new to him, and he never really was in the mood for kicking anyone in shape like a few of his colleagues always seemed to be.

He banged his fist on a table several times, drawing the attention of at least half the populace, an accomplishment in itself, "Alright," he cried, "Make sure you all get back to work-" With a peer back into the pot, he added, "And there's still a lot of work to do."

A few of the younger workers let out a deep breath of relief, only seconds earlier fearing they might all have been pummeled to death for such insolence.

* * *

Leiamon apprehensively started on her first potato, hastily setting the other four off to the side. Apparently, Yoimon, who was sitting right next to her, had just done the same thing, but her eyes were glued down below, either focusing on her potato or the ancient table's grains.

She could feel her face beginning to flush scarlet and grow feverish. . . How should she start? What would she sa-

"Uhm, I'm sorry if Rao was being a jerk to your friend," Yoimon apologized, scratching the back of his head earnestly, "Sometimes he can be like that."

"Oh, don't worry about it," Leiamon laughed, lifting her face to Yoimon's eyes, "By the looks of it, Taramon didn't let it get to her."

Yoimon's lips smirked as he recalled the scene only moments ago, "Yeah, she really took care of him," he chuckled, "Did your friend really hit him with a water blast?"

Leiamon nodded, "Yeah, Tara's been doing water magic like that for a while now- as long as I can remember at least," she remarked offhandedly.

"Wow, that's pretty cool... Not that many others have even started to study magic like that- nothing beyond the basic stuff we all have to study."

Leiamon's eyebrows raised as she noticed Yoimon was clearly interested by Tara's prowess, "Oh. . . well, you know, I do magic too," she muttered softly.

Suddenly, Yoimon's head flinched back suddenly with astonishment, "Really? That's awesome!" he exclaimed cheerfully, making Leiamon smile, "The two of you are probably way ahead of the rest of us in terms of magic."

"Well, we all do have our strengths," Leiamon stated.

"Yeah, definitely," Yoimon agreed, "I'd say that my one real strength would have to be running- I guess it might be because I have a single-tracked mind," he grinned sheepishly at his own pun.

"I can tell you're really committed," Leiamon put in before tentatively adding, "-because I've seen you jogging down the street a lot."

"Oh, really?" Yoimon simpered, a light blush setting into his complexion, "Well, I guess that would make sense- I really haven't alternated my jogging route in a while," he nodded, "So, where do you live? Since you've seen me jogging, I'm probably familiar with the area."

Leiamon's lips slowly curled into a subconcious smirk of joy. Everything WAS on the right track!

"Well, Tara and I share a room in the Blueroof dorm," Leiamon gladly admitted, "Our apartment's one on the second floor, and it has a patio facing the street."

"Oh, well, then it wouldn't be that hard to scope me out," Yoimon responded, smiling, "Yeah, I know where you're talking about- the Blueroof dorm's right around the end of my jogging route, although, I don't live that far off myself; I stay at the Redroof dorm, right next to the hot spring area they have there- not that many people still use it though, not after that huge bathhouse moved in down the block."

Leiamon quickly scrutinized her current potato for any remaining skin, and then set it aside with the other four, "Wow. . . I'm through five potatoes already? That went by pretty fast."

"Time flies," Yoimon shrugged as he finished off what seemed to be only his second potato.

Leiamon picked up her peeler again and held out her other hand, "Here, let me help you," she urged.

"Oh, sure," Yoimon nodded, as Leiamon went ahead and grabbed one of his potatoes. Focusing intently on the work in head of her, Leiamon's peeler gracefully, but also very carefully glided over the skin swiftly with smooth, round motions. She held the potato firmly with her free hand turned it around in turn with the peeler skinning the spud.

And in only less than a minute, the potato was bare, its offwhite color exposed for all the world to see and its brown skin all in one, long, winding peel.

"Wow, you're pretty good at this," Yoimon acclaimed, really impressed with Leiamon's job, "I didn't know you were so handy with a knife."

"Well, I tend to work a little faster when I'm focused," Leiamon nodded. However, she looked a little more critically at her own work, "Well, there still are some stray skins here and there," she admitted, peeling those away, "And some skin gets buried in the deeper eyes, you have to pick those parts out."

"Yeah, but still-" Yoimon persisted brightly.

"You're right," Leiamon nodded, looking at Yoimon's warm brown eyes, "Nobody's completely perfect, and I am learning, after all," she adknowledged, grabbing another potato, "Well, cooking that is."

"You cook too?"

"Oh no," Leiamon smiled, holding up both her full hands, "It's only something I do on the side in my free time, like a hobby," she said as she began to peel the new potato, "When I heard we were going to work in the kitchen, I got a little excited. I thought we were all actually going to make something, and not just peel potatoes- I should have known we were just going to end up preparing the ingredients for the real chefs," she chuckled.

Just then, a water droplet fell down onto the wooden face of the table.

Leiamon peered up from her work to see none other than Yoimon's friend, Raomon standing behind them, a little paler than before. Another bead of water formed at the tip of one of his locks of hair. His black clothes still seemed to be saturated with water; in fact, his whole body still seemed to be drenched and dripping, for the most part.

"Oh, hey, Rao," Yoimon addressed his friend, "You're still wet?" he asked, a little incredulously.

"You bet I'm still wet!" he snapped. Immediately, he started to shake his head swiftly from side to side, water droplets spraying everywhere. Once he stopped, a big, fat droplet slid down one of his stray locks and splattered onto the floor. Then, he continued to shake his head from side to side, water still spraying all over the place.

"Now you're getting everyone wet," Yoimon sighed, getting bombarded by a few dewdrops himself.

"You see?" Raomon scowled in frustration, ringing out his slack, black shirt, heavy with water, "I'm still wet. . . whatever I do, I can't dry myself off!" he cried, taking a nearby towel and trying to wipe his now moist, clammy hands.

Leiamon gasped, her eyes widening a little as she did so.

Immediately, Raomon latched onto that expression, and faced Leiamon, "Hey, what's that? I bet you know what that's really going on here- I bet you know what that witch did to me!" he exclaimed, launching himself towards Leiamon.

"Now, Rao-" Yoimon started, but Leiamon stood her ground and propelled herself toward Raomon's belligerant, dripping figure.

"First of all, she's not a witch, she's my friend- and she has a name; it's Taramon," Leiamon snapped back.

Raomon harrumphed, "Well, then, what did Taramon or whatever her name is do to me?"

"Well, obviously she didn't just spray you with water," Leiamon said, "Now, I think what she did was. . . uhm," Leiamon stammered, "-used a certain spell that sprayed you with water?"

Raomon was clearly not impressed, "What's the difference?" he snarled.

"Oh, will you relax?" asked a familiar voice, "You might be wet and unable to dry out for now, but you should be well in an hour or two- just hope you don't catch a cold or anything in those two hours."

"Taramon," Leiamon nodded as she saw her best friend arrive on the scene.

"Well, if it isn't the witch!" the damp Digimon growled, clenching his fists.

Yoimon stepped behind him, clasping a hand on his saturated shoulders, "She does have a point, Rao. Maybe you should just calm down."

Raomon gritted his teeth, "Come on, Yoimon. We're going," he urged his friend on.

"Hey, now wait a minute, Rao," Yoimon shook his head

"The first block's going to end any minute now," the dripping Raomon added, "So you might as well say your goodbyes, and I'll say my good riddances."

Taramon turned to face him, "Well, I, for one, am glad to say I won't be seeing you anytime soon," she said saccharinely, closing her eyes and shooting him a smile just as overly sweet.

"Same here, witch!" he yapped loudly, taking off, but not before adding, "It's off to scrubbing the floors for me."

. . .

That last inadvertantly acrid remark struck Taramon like a sledgehammer violently swinging down upon a small ceramic box labeled, 'Sanity'. As that single moment stretched exaggeratedly to an entire hour, her eyes slowly widened, bigger and whiter, the long strands of her blue hair stood on its edge, her complexion paled, and her clenched teeth gaped wider and wider in utter shock, disbelief, and terror.

Taramon might have just then given in and shrieked, "WHAAAT!?!"

But instead, she shut her eyes and bit her lip, trembling while she bided her inner hysteria.

Just then, a loud pealing clash resounded from the front throughout the entire room. Nearly the entire room diverted their attentions to the head of the room, where their Ogremon proctor was standing. He was carrying a large wooden spoon, and had just apparently struck the suspended top of the large pot the potatoes were currently floating around in, "Alright, then," he called out, "Finish up- get your last potatoes in, clean up, wash and deposit your peelers, and proceed onto your next station."

A sizable swarm of students formulated a messy procession to the front pot to set down their final potatoes, while a few others scurried around wheeling around bins to throw all the leftover potato scraps and skisn in. Once again, chaos disguised in an orderly fashion ensued.

Before confronting the mad mob of workmates, Yoimon turned around to face Leiamon, "Well, it's really been nice meeting you," he said, "Although, I'm sorry it kinda ended the way it did- Hey, maybe we should meet up again. That would be pretty cool," he suggested, making Leiamon's heart fly leaps and bounds.

"Sure," a vividly blushing Leiamon agreed softly.

Just then, she recalled the schedule, and tapped Yoimon's shoulder before he went up, "Wait- do you know where you're headed next? I know I'm dishwashing-"

"Oh, good question," Yoimon nodded, "Let's see. . ." he pondered for a few seconds, "I think I'm dishwashing too," he smiled, before chuckling, "It's kinda funny how that worked out, huh?"
13412211211211112211221212211111.title: Conversation Over the Potato Peels

134122112112111122112212122111111.content:
Leiamon blushed slighlty, glancing ever so discreetly to her left, where Yoimon stood washing and rinsing the dishes that had accumulated over the day, perhaps the last several days, before handing them offf to her to dry and stack neatly in a pile at the counter they were working at.

After everyone had finished putting in their potatoes into the pot in Block 1, everyone had proceeded to to meander to their second block of chores, some more enthusiastic than others.

Namely, Taramon and Raomon.

After discovering that they would have together, or at least be in close proximity of one another for another work period, the two had exploded.

Or rather, Raomon exploded while Taramon barely restrained herself from blasting him with another jet of water. After Ogremon had dismissed them, Taramon had left as quickly as she could in heels, which was surprisingly swift, actually, with only a brief farewell to Leiamon.

The others had then gradually filled out, with Yoimon and herself bringing up the rear of the pack, a distressed Raomon grumbling behind them with his hands in his pockets.

Out in the sunlight again, if only briefly, the group began to chatter away as everyone broke off into smaller clusters as they headed to Block 2.

Leiamon giggled to herself as she dried another dish and stacked it in with the other clean ones.

She and Yoimon had almost gotten lost.

While both of them knew they had to wash dishes, they were both unsure of which kitchen to report to, as there were countless kitchens throughout the city and the campuses of the ten temples.

Luckily, they had ran into another digimon who had Dish washing duty, or actually, a friend of a digimon who had dish washing duty, who pointed out to them that Block 2 Dish washing was held at the kitchen in an off campus administration building of the Temple of Steel, one of many in the city that answered questions of aspiring students concerning various matters about the Temple they represented as well as tested the abilities of said aspiring students.

As such, in addition to those who worked there, off campus administration buildings also operated small dorm buildings(usually marked with the clor or symbol of a Temple) to house students who were oficially being looked over and tested by the Temple of which the administation building belonged to.

This in turn, prodcued a lot of dishes, with aspiring students coming and going at random times and comsuming what they could when they could.

"Sure you don't want me to wash the dishes Yoimon?" Leiamon asked, noting that Yoimon's hands had beocme a bit...pruned. "I really don't mind. I mean, usually Taramon washes dishes at the dorm, but I know how to."

Yoimon chuckled and smiled at her amiably.

"No worries. I'm used to it by now. Raomon cooks in our dorm, and I'm the one usually washing dishes." He said with a sigh. "Of course...he's never let me cook anything since that one time I tried to make sashimi and it ended up tasting all sugary..."

Beliamon went rigid and chuckled nervously for a second, before looking at Yoimon to see that he wasn't joking.

"Hehe...well then...I guess he does have a point there..." She muttered awkwardly as she went back to drying dishes, then glancing around to take in the kitchen they were working in more.

Honestly, she'd seen better kitchens. Actually, the Temple of Steel wasn't exactly her favroite temple o begin with. Everything about it wreeked or...order. And everything was cold and impersonal, or so she heard.

If she were to use their kitchens as evidence, it was probably true.

The kitchen in this administration building, one representinhg the Temple of Steel, was the definition of cold and impersonal.

The floor was of a stark, white tile that stretched the length of the kitchen, which was quite long indeed. Light was provided by stiff, chrome fixtures affixed to the ceiling every few feet down the center of the kitchen, over various island counters that stood in the center as preparation areas while counters on either side of the central island countertops provided additional workspace as well as locations for appliances, such as stoves and refrigerators, and of course the sinks the Block 2 workers were using for dishwashing duty. The only windows in the room were placed high on the wall, unreachable and, Leiamon ventured, unopenable.

Turning back to her work, Leiamon shivered. This was not what a kitchen should be like. There was no way she, at least, could cook in such a stifling environment.

Closing her eyes, she brought up one of her fonder memories of cooking in Taramon and her own dorm.

**

Leiamon sighed to herself deeply, breathing in the rich smell of the spaghetti simmering on the stove.

Standing up, she wiped her hands on her apron before brushing away a few drops of sweat on her forehead.

It was Spring, and everyone had been excited to finally be able to get outdoors again

"Its almost ready Tara!" She called with a smile, sticking her head around the corner to where she could see out the front door, where Taramon was diligently watering her flowerbed, nurturing the small buds that would bloom in a few weeks.

Her friend turned to her and grinned.

"Thanks Lei! You know how I love your cokking! I'm almost done here, I'll be in soon!" Her friend replied before turning back to her work.

Leiamon giggled.

"You and your flowers, Taramon." She said, before returning to stir her spaghetti somewhere, ocassionally glancing out the window, down at the busy streets below.

The sounds of students or those aspiring to be students running around and laughing, the shouts of vendors selling various odds and ends, and the occasional magical sounds lifted her spirits.

It was as enlightening as her spaghetti was tasty, if she did say so herself.

Making sure said spaghetti was in no danger of burning, she stuck her head out the window and took in a deep breath of fresh air, scented by the blooming of fresh spring flowers and was delighted in the cool breeze against her face.

It was a beautiful day.

In the distance the waters of the Temple of Water could be seen glittering in the sunlight, the turrets of the Temple of Light matching theier brilliance in the east. To the north, the forests that marked the campus of the Temple of Wood were swaying in the gentle breeze, a vivid emerald color with the return of spring. Even the Temple of Ice, which she had seen earlier in the day to the south, was shining stupendously today, even though its patron season had given way.

And the sky!

It was so perfectly blue today, not a cliud to be seen in any direction.

Turning her eyes to the street, Leiamon noted that the people were as joyous as the Temples seemed, and their actions reflected the sounds she had heard earlier. Everyone was meandering along or having gun or selling their wares with a smile on their face.

'I'm so glad I'm here.' Leiamon thought. 'I'm so happy that I can...wait...who's that guy? he's moving pretty fast.'

Leiamon leaned down out of the window a bit more, to catch someone bobbing and weaving through the crowd with a runner's pace, far faster than anyone else on the street.

'Is he...working out?' Leiamon noted, absently notcing that this digimon was quite slim, if not muscled, and as he came closer, she noticed he was quite handsome too.

His brown, chocolate hair fluttering a bit in the breeze where it wasn't a bit dampened from sweat, was held back by a red hairband. He was indeed quite fit and was dressed for running, and powered his way down the busy street with a confident stride, yet was always careful to never bump into anyone.

'Wow...he's really...cute...' Leiamon barely heard herself think as she leaned out of the window further as the mystery runner came closer.

Closer...

Closer......

Closer.........

"Lei!"

**

Leiamon blushed, coming back to the present.

It had been at that point that she had almost fallen out of the window. Luckily, Taramon had just came into the kitchen and caught her friend before she tumbled down out into the street, possibly on who she now knew as Yoimon.

'That would have been a fantastic way to meet..." Leiamon thought sarcastically. 'Hi, I'm Leiamon. Sorry about falling on you from a two-story window. I was entranced by your beaughty.'

That had been...what? A little over a year ago? Time had really flown since then. Here she was, lessthan three feet away from the digimon she had admired from a distance for so long, and they were actually speaking!

"Leiamon?"

"Eep!" Leiamon squeeked, brought out of her thoughts by Yoimon's voice, and glanced at him shyly.

Seeing that she had been daydreaming, he laughed.

"Lei, I THINK that one dish is dry now...in fact, I've never seen one more clean.

Leiamon blinked, then looked to her hands to discover that she had been polishing the same dish for quite a while now and a fairly sized stack had piled up during her daydreaming.

"Gah!" She exclaimed, putting the dish she had been holding onto the stack of clean dishes and resuming her task with a renwed passion. "Oh, if I don't hurry, I won't catch up! Oi!"

Yoimon laughed heartily again and waited a few minutes for her to catch up to him before resuming his own job of washing.

"You looked really spaced for a second there." He noted with a grin. "What were you thinking of?...Er, that is if you don't mind me asking."

Leiamon giggled as he hastily added that last part and then smiled serenely to herself.

"I...was thinking of the first time I saw someone.." She said dreamily, catching Yoimon's attention.

"Oh?" He asked, looking at her awkwardly from the sides of his eyes.

She nodded and gazed out the window, small as it was, but delighted that she could still see the sky.

"A little over a year ago. The sky was so blue that day...so blue." Leiamon mumbled dreamily to herself. "And my spaghetti was good too."

Next to her, Leiamon hadn't noticed, but Yoimon had jumped a bit at the mention of spaghetti and the pretty day a year or so ago, and now wore a slightly shocked expression on his face.

Then he too, smiled and the pair continued their chore of washing and drying dishes as sunlight was calmly filtered into the room.
134122112112111122112212122111111.title: Block 2 Commences!

1341221121121111221122121221111112.content:
"You know," Yoimon started tentatively and a bit softly, breaking the few minutes where scrubbing and running water were the only noises to be heard, "A little bit more than a year or two ago, I guess something happened to me that changed my life."

"Really?" Leiamon asked, now interested, prompting him to continue while staying intent on the dish in front of her.

Yoimon nodded, "Yeah. . . that was the first time I saw the Ayzahn Ra Marathon for real," he muttered lowly.

"Oh. . ." Leiamon looked out the slim window. She could remember all the fuss about that big race taking place in the city just fine. But why wasn't she there to see it?

Had that been one of the days when she geniunely overslept and had to miss out on the day's festivities to do chores in the afternoon? How ironic would that be?

Maybe she was busy with something else at the time. . . Had it been one of those occasional instances where she been training with her mentor?

"You know it's really a big deal to be a top runner in the Marathon- you have to have a lot of guts to hold your own for that amount of distance, " Yoimon stated, "The course's supposed to be long and challenging, and the competition's wild- hundreds, maybe even thousands enter, but still, time after time, dozens make it through. . . and on that day, I saw the winner burst through the finish line, and collapse to the ground wearing the biggest grin I've ever seen, just before every one else came crashing through. . . "

Yoimon paused, before shaking his head in disbelief moments later, "He must have been the happiest guy in the world..."

"After I saw that race, I became determined to run the next time it was held. That's when I started taking my training and running more seriously," Yoimon nodded as he finished washing the last dish.

Then, at that moment, he froze, staring back at the opaque reflection the soapy-film covered plate sent back to him.

". . . I guess I've come a long way since that day, years ago," Yoimon stated softly before a firm grin appeared on his face and a low chuckle started to resound from his mouth, "Wow. . . I can remember my first week out running like it was only a month ago or something."

Leiamon could tell just by looking at the growing smile and subconcious chucklings that ensued that Yoimon was taking another trip down Memory Lane. . . or, maybe another run down one of Ayzahn Ra's streets.

Suddenly, Yoimon's eyes darted from the plate to look to Leiamon. "Hey, you know the street right outside the dorms' area, the one with the bakery on the corner?" Yoimon asked her, a little bit excitedly.

"Yeah," Leiamon nodded, an image of the bakeshop immediately popping into her mind, "How couldn't I? I pass by it almost every day."

Yoimon's brown eyes seemed to be laughing and he peered at her, almost emitting high spirits from the place he stood, "Well. . . wanna hear something embarrassing?" he inquired.

Leiamon almost shivered with excitement; now he wanted to let her in on a little secret, "Sure!" she exclaimed.

"Well, not that many people know this," Yoimon began very calmly, before taking a brief pause, "When I first starting taking my morning runs, well- this is kind of embarassing. . . every morning, as I made the turn around the corner, I bolted smack into the bakery signpost on the corner!"

A bright blush now spread through his complexion, yet a small smile still remained.

"And I kept on getting hit in the head by that bakery sign every single morning- it must have been hanging too low or short, or maybe it was even out of my line of sight... But when I made that same turn every morning, I always never saw it coming or even remembered why my head was sore. . ." Yoimon shook his head incredulously and chuckled again, "Man, I really got some nasty bruises on my head, all from that sign."

As he stacked up the last dish, Yoimon nodded again, shaking away any further reminiscings before stating, "Every day, I stretch and run my routes around blocks of the city, anywhere around town- sometimes, I even go through parts of the route that the Marathon has used in the past, just to get familiar," he admitted before adding softly, "I guess you could say it's my dream to one day make it into the Marathon and come out on top."

Leiamon noticed that even among a sheepish expression and an increasingly deep blush, Yoimon's eyes had a tone of firm determination and resolve within them.

"Yoimon, that's great!" Leiamon piped in, blushing a little herself.

"Shucks," Yoimon muttered, his blush becoming even more vibrant, as he snatched a towel and subconciously dried the plate he just washed, "It's kinda dumb, don't you think?"

"No," Leiamon shook her head, "Yoimon, I think that's great," she repeated again, "You shouldn't give up on it or be ashamed if that's your dream," she nodded.

"Really?" Yoimon asked, looking at her, "Thanks, Leiamon," he said, softly, taking another dish to dry.

A soft silence came, and their blushes started to subside and transform into warm, genunine smiles.

****

Shortly after Leiamon and Yoimon, who had chosen to lend a helping hand, had just barely finished drying the teetering tower of dishes to dry, the twosome were dismissed off to Block 3.

Over the last set of dishes, the pair had already discussed the final block. Perhaps it was not only Leiamon's disappointment when they exchanged the fact that they wouldn't be working together for the remainder of the work day. Yoimon had to go cut firewood for some temple's hearths and furnaces that night, even though it was the beginning of summer.

On the other hand, Leiamon couldn't join him, as she had to go wash sheets with Taramon, who she had planned to meet up with at the bookkeeping building where said best friend was washing floors.

Even though she had passed this way with Yoimon before entering the cold confines of the Temple of Steel's campus adminstration building, Leiamon was still surprised to see the stark differences between the inside and outside of the building.

The campus itself was located a short distance from the main core of the city, a much more calm and quiet area where students in question could perform at their peak. Leiamon guessed that other adminstration buildings had similar locations, but she knew for sure that the Temples themselves were much more distant, and much, much more grand.

Once the two had emerged through the polished steel double doors that swung heavily behind them, they could sense the thick, muggy atmosphere around them. Those same skies that Leiamon recalled were so blue seemed a bit more somber than before, as a dim, smoky cloud passed over the sun.

"It's going to rain in a while," Leiamon noted as the duo found themselves at a busy crossway.

"Uhm, well, I guess this is where we part ways?" Yoimon said hesitantly.

"I guess so," Leiamon said reluctantly.

"Well, I just want you to know. . ." Yoimon started before taking a deep breath, "That I really enjoyed talking to you, and. . . uhm, well. . ."

"Yes?"

"Oh- never mind. It was nothing, really," Yoimon dismissed hastily, before taking a look at her and sighing again. "I had a great time talking to you today, and well, I wouldn't mind it if we met up again. You know, we don't live too far apart, and I'd really like to get to know you better."

Then came a pause that seemed way out of proportion for both of them.

"Sure, I'll try to keep in touch," Leiamon smiled softly, knowing that she'd do a lot more than 'try'.

"Cool," Yoimon nodded, turning hesitantly as he walked down the path, "So, uhm, I guess I'll see you later."

Leiamon returned the nod and couldn't hold back a soft giggle, "See you soon!"

With that, Leiamon watched Yoimon break into a jog, and after a few moments, he was gone.

* * *

"If I don't hurry up, I will be late for Block 3 after all!" Leiamon thought to herself as she frantically sped down the busy, puddled streets of Ayzahn Ra, "And not to mention soaked..." .

She must have took a wrong turn somewhere. "I've lived here for as long as I can remember, I can't be lost," Leiamon reassured herself. Even though she had resided in Ayzahn Ra for seemingly forever, this was a sector of the city Leiamon didn't frequent as much, so as a result, not everything was as familiar to Leiamon.

"Still," Leiamon thought offhandedly, "This place is a little far off for doing chores. . ."

Nevertheless, Leiamon pressed on, keeping in mind the advice a vendor had given her a few blocks down, underneath a large wooden umbrella. After a little explanation, Leiamon found out that the vendor had seen a large herd of students-in-training stampeding off to the East Sector of the city to go wash floors in East Central Library, one of the largest in Ayzahn Ra, as it was well overdue for cleaning. Leiamon was only a little familiar with the area in general, and needed directions to get to the library, to which the vendor gladly helped her out.

One more turn, and Leiamon found herself at one of Ayzahn Ra's smaller plazas. Sturdy benches were to be found on all sides. A fountain with running water in beautiful arcs and streams was to be found in the center of the cobblestoned open square, faithfully spouting water in spite of the light shower from above. Here and there, a few odd peddlers were stationed, mainly selling used books, Leiamon noted.

Turning around, Leiamon's eyes widened as she looked up and saw twin sets of marble staircases directly climbing up a short hill that flattened out into a terrace; resting on this was very large library sweeping up several stories. Even though it was fairly high up and a slight walking distance away, Leiamon could still spot it among the few shops and stalls in the plaza.

"This must be it," Leiamon told herself as she started towards the stone flight of stairs closest to her. Taking a guess, Leiamon had some time on her hands, about a little more than an hour, so she really wasn't in a hurry. Although, if she could find Taramon soon, then maybe the twosome would make it to their final chore, worry free.

* * *

Panting heavily, Leiamon brushed her shoes against the carpet at the library's entryway. It had really started to downpour on her ascent up the stairs, and an image of the drenched Raomon came to mind.

Well, at least her final job of washing sheets was one that involved water as well. . .

Nevertheless, Leiamon opened the inner doorway of the library at once, and was swept away by its lofty, flat ceiling that arched formidably over a vast array of almost equally tall bookshelves. Even more alarming was the carved sign that read 'Ground Floor,' in front of her.

It must have been bigger inside than it was outside!

Not wanting to wait around or waste any more time, Leiamon trudged off, determined to find her friend on her own within the next handful of minutes.

***

Peering outside the deep-set window, Leiamon shook her head in pure disbelief.

It had already stopped raining already and the sky was clearing up. . . Already she had spent more than two handfuls of minutes and then some, and still, she had found no progress in locating Taramon.

They weren't in any of the lengthy stretches of bookcases, lined with ladders and stuffed with all kinds of thick, leatherbound volumes, thin paperbacks, manuscripts, new magazines, ancient scrolls, and mysterious looking boxes alike.

They weren't tidying up the rows of desks in alcoves. They weren't cleaning the desks used for studying.

Not a single slacker was relaxing on any cushioned sofas or chairs in one of the reading rooms, but an elderly Digimon had decided to fall asleep, face forward into his book.

Nor were any of them to be found mopping the hallways leading from any one of these rooms to any other. And she hadn't even begun to cover anything past the second floor, let alone even venture down the spiraling staircases to the lower levels!

"This might take a while. . ." Leiamon sighed to herself as she marched back down to the chamber she had originally entered at first, and waited in front of an old, sturdy looking counter that must have been sitting there for the past three hundred years.

Tilting her head up, Leiamon peered around, looking for any signs of librarians or even just assistance in general.

Moments passed, and still nobody came, aside from the occasional Digimon busy browsing the aisles or skimming a thick book

"This place is enormous, they could be anywhere," Leiamon scowled at her abysmal situation, before a sharp twist came to mind, "Or Taramon could have even left by now. . . Maybe she's looking for me, wondering where I could have run off to." Leiamon tapped her forehead ungently and let out a deep breath of frustration. . . was she even supposed to be here in the first place?

"Excuse me, could I help you?" asked a nearby, seasoned-looking Digimon carrying a sizable bundle of books, leaning down to glare at her suddenly. His manueverings across the floor were mysteriously adroit and scurrying.

"Oh, yes," Leiamon smiled sheepishly, "Hi, I'm looking for a group of-"

Swiftly, the Digimon shifted the weight of all the books over to one arm as he freed his other and raised a sole finger, "Shh. . . please try to remember that this is a library, after all," he tried to explain as quietly and as polite as he could, keeping his voice at a crisp rustle that barely could reach Leiamon's hearing, let alone any of the walls.

"Uhm," Leiamon stammered before lowering her voice, "I'm looking for a group of students-in-training that were sent to clean the floors of this library. Did you happen to see them? Could you please tell me where they are?"

The knowledgable looking Digimon lowered his head and hunched shoulders and scratched it with his free hand, "Now, let's see," he breathed lightly, "Oh yes, that's right, they were supposed to come around sometime this month. . . and it's about high time they got here; this place hasn't seen anyone take a mop to the floor who was really serious about it in, well, probably half a century."

Recoiling at bit at the suggested timespan, Leiamon sighed, "So you haven't seen them around, then?"

"No," the Digimon answered honestly, "But I do pay attention to the happenings of this library.

Much to my irration, I've heard the hastening footsteps of what could only be hopeful young Digimon, who would otherwise have no business or desire to be here, scampering up and down the stairs in my rounds- even they can remember that this is a library, after all, and silence must be paramount. . ." the Digimon shuddered. "Thank goodness they should be done and dismissed out in no less than a half an hour," he said in his clipped, faint voice.

"Under half an hour? Well, thank you," Leiamon said as the Digimon nodded and crept off, journeying down a long aisle to do his business.

"Under half an hour. . ." Leiamon repeated to herself, thinking of all the time she had to spend until then. Well, she could leave the library and wait outside for Tara. . . the place did give off a little bit of an eerie touch. . . but then again, that very feeling and mystery of what might be out there waiting for her crept down her spine, teased her fascinations, and made her all the more interested to stay and look at some of the vast oceans of books belonging to the ancient edifice. . . at least until Tara showed up.

***

"It looks like we're almost finished," Taramon muttered to herself, washing away the accumulated dust and dirt of a decade or two off the stone floor, taking immense care not to soil or soak her dress. A few others had just now started to pack up their materials and take leave. "Although, even I have to admit, this really has taken a long time," she thought.

She had sure been in there for quite a while. . . probably because it was a smaller group of workers divided up throughout the expansive library with at least the intent of tidying it up, probably something that hadn't been attempted in at least a lifetime.

Luckily for her, Taramon had yet to see neither hide nor hair of that arrogant Raomon since they broke off into groups.

Hopefully, his group's done and all over with, Taramon thought to herself, shaking her head at the mere thought of him.

"Good riddance," she muttered bitterly under her breath as cautiously knelt down to polish off the very last bit of grimy floor.

But Taramon had spoken too soon. . .

One second, Taramon was on her knees, vigorously scrubbing. . . and the next, there came a firm push from behind, and she knocked to the ground and sent sliding down the saturated stone hallway, which was both soapy and dirty at the same time.

With a splash, her arm crashed into the corner of a wall. Shock spread throughout her body from the impact as the water droplets slid down.

The smallest chuckle sounded down the hall as Taramon braced herself from the shock and picked herself up. As she steadily rose to her feet, Taramon gazed down at her now dripping dress, the front of which had been entirely drenched. To add to that, black smears of grime streaked across her once nice clothes.

As she slowly turned her head upward, Taramon's eyes were overshadowed by her dripping locks of hair before they burst into flame and started to glare directly down the hall, searching toward the only one who could possibly be responsible for this.

Her icy eyes peered down the hall, but Taramon only saw nothing a sparkling clean hallway, a staircase bound downwards, and a few other workmates finishing up the job, packing up their materials.

However, her ears revealed to her the screechy sounds of wet, boots that were, no doubt, black, scrambling frantically down a flight of stairs.

Scowling loudly, she deftly slammed away her sponge, and dumped her bucket violently into a large pot of dirty water, and quickly pursued his lead, stomping down the flight of stairs.

***
A quick scan of faded gold-leaf titling suddenly recalled the memories Leiamon had just shared with Yoimon earlier, once more.

"Hmm?" Leiamon grabbed another thick-bound book from the shelf that was so heavy, it required the usage of both her arms and a little bit of sweat, "This entire book is all on how to prepare pasta to perfection?" she alliterated, as she skimmed over a few pages.

Shaking her head in disbelief, Leiamon returned the wide book to its original postion on the shelf.

This place is amazing, Leiamon thought to herself. Over the past twenty minutes or so that she had been waiting for Tara, Leiamon had been practically poring over the writings, and staring in awe at the sheer volume the library had acquired. Now that she had the time, she could finally take a moment and appreciate it all. . . and notice all of the cookbooks and spellbooks among other things.

This is really incredible, Leiamon thought- even though she wasn't known to be the biggest bookworm, she did have a yen for cooking, and when it came to magic, well, she was next to Tara, going above and beyond her own level and making sense of how she could get it to work in her own life. The two sometimes bought such books that they could use later on with spare money at the market district every now and again.

And imagine all this at our disposal, Leiamon sighed taking a look at the already seemingly infinite hallways of shelves soaring to a high ceiling. And this is just the first floor. . . I wonder what might be on the others, or in the basement floors, Leiamon thought steathily, or any secret floors, areas that only select personel are allowed in, and only choice members of the most elite Temple students are allowed to even think about reading a word from. . .

Leiamon rustled her hair briefly. That was her speculations getting to her, if not anything else, then her imagination.

But even still, she thought, I'm probably not supposed to be here in the first place. . . I don't see any other trainees in here checking out books or reading, and that Digimon from before seemed pretty disturbed to see anyone half-grown set foot within a mile of the premises. He was so worked up just because of the nois-

Just then, an echoing stomping sounded off distantly behind Leiamon that suddenly grew louder and louder; they footsteps that seemed to be bounding down a staircase frantically, jumping down two steps at a time to escape, or perhaps pursue something, or someone.

Slowly twisting around, Leiamon's eyes looked out to a staircase which had its flight worked into a wall. . . The echoes became clearer, crisper, and louder, and suddenly, there came a clap as whoever was bolting down the stairs suddenly emerged.

Leiamon's eyes widened as she saw it was...
1341221121121111221122121221111112.title: A Brief Intermission

choices: In the morning, Beliamon reports to Cherubimon?
13412211211211112211221212211111122.content:
Leiamon blinked, watching as Raomon scrabled down the remainder of the stairs, his black boots squeeking as he did so.

He looked as if he was on the run from the devil.

"Raomon?" Leiamon voiced as the black-clad digimon raced past her, seemingly not noticing her.

Looking back, Raomon shot Leiamon an urgent look.

"Sorry! Gotta run! No time for-" He began, but was suddenly cut off.

"AHA!" A loud shout was emitted throughout the library, one that Leiamon was sure would make the older digimon she had seen earlier jump, either from surprise or indignance.

Spinning, Leiamon caught sight of her friend, only not quite as...clean as she had last seen her.

Taramon in question was hurrying down the last few stairs, a murderous look in her eyes, which were overshadowed by her dripping and unkept bangs.

"Daaamn..." Leiamon muttered, and turned again to give Raomon, who appeared to be frozen with fear, a pitied look.

This didn't last long, however, as the prankster muttered a few choice words before turning heel and running- no sprinting- for his life.

"Oh, Raomon, what's the matter? A big, strong, masculine digimon such as yourself running away from a little, helpless digimon like me?" Taramon taunted, a smirk coming to her face as the evil glint in her eyes only increased.

Stopping ever so slowly, Raomon swished around and gave the bluenette a wary look. Taramon's smirk widened to show her teeth.

Leiamon mentally smacked herself, having long stepped to the side to ensure her own safety.

'Idiot.' She thought, 'Should have kept running while you had the chance.

Swiftly, in one speedy motion, Taramon had brought down her left arm to point at Raomon with her index and middle mingers.

He looked at her oddly.

Following the example of her left arm, Taramon then brought down her right, only this arm was balled into a fist. Slowly, she began to pull her right arm back to herself as her eyes narrowed in on Raomon. A light blue glow began to swim around her hands.

Leiamon chuckled to herself. He was going to learn the hard way...again.

Sensing danger, Raomon had turned to run again and was nearly to exit...

But, before he could reach his salvation, Taramon uncurled her right fist, unleashing her attack.

"Frozen Spray!" Leiamon's roomate shouted, sending an array of swift, arrow-like jets of water at Raomon, or rather, Raomon's feet.

As the jets of water hit Raomon, he stopped and stumbled slightly, most likely taken aback by the low temperatures of the jets now covering his feet and legs.

Attempting to recover himself, Raomon again made a a mad dash for the door.

Only he couldn't. The icy jets Taramon had shot at him had encased his feet and some parts of his legs in just that: ice.

"Nice shot, Tara." Leiamon remarked somewhat hesitantly from her spot on the sidelines. She may have been Taramon's friend, but that by no means measnt that she was any less susceptable to one of her fits.

Turning to see Leiamon for what seemed to be the first time, the rage slowly ebbed from Taramon's eyes and she issued a deep sigh.

"My marskmanship was off. I was aiming higher." Taramon replied, sashaying over to her prisoner, looking all the part of a princess at a ball, despite her disheveled state. "And it's been a while since I've fused elements. I'm surprised I pulled it off as well as I did.

"Higher?" Raomon squeeked as Taramon approached him.

Leiamon mentally raised her eyebrow at a squeek coming from Raomon. It would have been kind of cute had Raomon been in a different position than his current one and had she not been completely and utterly devoted to Yoimon.

Taramon cackled to herself.

"Oh, yes. I'm sure you know where." She said with a laugh before eyeing him as a rather hungry cat eyes a rather plump mouse.

Raomon gulped.

"And what's with the ice anyway? I thought you were a water mage?" Raomon asked, attempting to wiggle himself free from the ice.

Tara snorted.

"Please. Even someone like you knows you can fuse elements. That was an Ice and Water fusion spell, obviously. And I specialize in water magic. That doesn't mean I can't wield any of the others. In fact, I can wield all of the elements to some extent with the exception of Earth. But REALLY, how hard is it to figure out? I mean its basically common knowledge. Why I'll have you know that..."

Leiamon massaged her temples as Taramon began to rant and sat down in one of the chairs she was thankful that lined the room. She suddenly had a headache.

Beliamon...

If Taramon didn't hurry up lecturing Raomon, they were all going to be late to 3rd Block. And then they would probably have to do afternoon chores again tomorrow. And it wouldn't be fun without at least having the prospect of perhaps being working in a block with Yoimon.

Beliamon.

Her head was pounding now. 'Gee...this was sudden.' Leiamon though to herself, the mental process causing her to wince as glancing in Taramon and Raomon's direction. They came through as blurry blobs. Despite her sudden headache, she could barely hear their bickering voices. 'At it again I see.'

Beliamon!

***

Leiamon blinked, adjusting her eyesight. Had it gotten darker? No, everythig was gray. And where was she?

Glancing arounf as her eyes gradually got used to the surroundings, she found herself to be on a balcony...or the ruins of one.

Wait...balcony?

A sharp intake of breath elicited her reaction as reality crashed down onto her.

She wasn't Leiamon, she was Beliamon. Leiamon was dead. She died quite a while ago. She wasn't with Raomon or Taramon. They were dead too. Everyone was dead. Even the city was dead.

"Beliamon? Sheesh, what's wrong with you? You'd think screaming in your ear would work..." Someone muttered from beside her, shocking her a tad.

She turned to see...Kouji? Yes Kouji.

Shaking her head wearily, Beliamon mentally noted to guard herslef more closely from now on. These visions were stirring up memories that were better left forgotten, especially now when she couldn't afford any weaknesses.

"...Beliamon?" Kouji asked again, looking at his captor with a look mized between worry and suspicion.

"If it isn't my favorite little human." Beliamon joked, smiling sweetly. "But on to business, do you need anything?"

Kouji blinked at her as if she had grown another head...or two.

"Well...I was just...seeing...if you were alive." He remarked rather blandly.

"Alive? Well, duh? I look alive don't I? At least I hope I do." Beliamon retorted, shifting to give herself a look here and there. As she did so she noted quite a bit of stiffness in her bones.

"Well, yeah....you LOOK alive, but you sure weren't acting alive up until a few seconds ago." Kouji said as he gave her a poke, just to make sure.

"Stop that." Beliamon chastised, swatting him away. "And what do you mean?"

"Well...when I found you you were sitting here, straight as a board, staring into space...or lack there of." Kouji said, gesturing towards the balcony's grand view of the non-existant sky.

"I...was?" Beliamon asked rather sheepishly. Yep. Reeeally needed to stop having vision...flashback..thingies.

Kouji only nodded as if he was telling a toddler that the sky was blue. Which would be true in most places, with the exception of Ayzahn Ra.

Shaking her head again, Beliamon sighed heavily.

"Well, that explains the stiffnes at least." She remarked before glancing at her 'prisoner' again. "But then...why were you looking for me? I thought you were asleep."

At this, Kouji's eyes widened and he blushed slightly.

"Oh, well I woke up a while ago and wondered where you were. Its not like you to stay in one place for a long time, at least I don't think it is." Kouji mumbled as he rubbed the back of his neck awkwardly. "And I was kind of...alittle bit.."

"What's that?" Beliamon prompted, but delighted that he had been concerned for her.

"And I was wondering...if...you had any snacks." Kouji admitted, and shouted when Beliamon stared at him in shock. "What?! Is it against the law for a guy to have a midnight snack around here?! I mean, not that you can even tell if its midnight or not..."

Beliamon's shocked visage was soon replaced by one of happiness as she smiled and gave his knee a quick pat, resisting to instead pet his paunch.

"Aha! I knew you'd see it my way sooner or later, Kouji!" She shouted in happiness, jumping up from the bench and quite a few of her bones popping.

Behind her, he only sighed.

"Oh, joy. Another chance for you to feed me and fulfill you duties to your employer. Like I need it. My clothes can't take much more." Kouji said, standing as well.

Examing him, Beliamon got a good look at the boy and chuckled mentally.

His clothes sure didn't leave much rom for thought, at least. The yellow shirt that Jouji wore under his jacket clearly outlined his expanding belly in addition to the twin indentations that indicated the started of breasts; and this was standing up. Beliamon imagined that his form's appearance must give him constant distress when he's sitting down or lounging. In addition to this, Beliamon also noted that his pants appeared a bit snug in the rear, not to mention that the boy was tugging at the seems quite a bit now.

Though....his progress still dwarfed that of his friends. Something had to be done about that. It was a shame Kouji actually exercised self-restraint when it came to food, unlike the others, especially the noisy one and the small child.

Chuckling nervously, Beliamon tugged Kouji off of the balcony and back into the hall, this time taking a side route in which she believed would deposit them near the kitchen, where she had stashed her food supplies.

"Please Kouji, you're just bloated. And don't worry about your appearance. I honestly still don't know why you do." She said, making a turn into a darker hallway and breaking out her ball of flame for light as she did so. At least the trance she had been in had seemed to have regenerated her magic energy.

She could almost feel Kouji roll his eyes.

"Well, if you don't take into account the many health detriments, there is the fact that...that no one makes fun of thin people..." Kouji retorted, ending a bit weakly.

Noticing this, and resisting the urge to question Kouji, Beliamon continued on her trek to the kitchens.

"Well...its not like I'm aiming to make you the size of a whale, Kouji. If that's what you're thinking, you're wrong. I'm only plumping you up. You're not going to die because of that." She chuckled. "You'll just be a bit more round. I find nothing wrong with that. And as far as scorn is concerned, you have friends. Friends that, if my guess is correct will stand by you through anything."

Kouji raised an eyebrow at that.

"How would you know anything about the others? And I even really known them that long either." He countered.

"Because I've been watching them, Kouji. Or rather, I've had people watching them for me. They're hearts are pure. They've accepted you. All you have to do is accpet them." Beliamon continued talking, knowing this was a serious subject for Kouji but trying to keep the tone of their conversation carefree and light.

Kouji snorted.

"First of all, I find it hard to believe you've been watching them. Secondly, I find it even harder to believe that you could know that they;re good people." He remarked. "Zoe, the girl, she's conceited. J.P, the big guy, he's arrogant. Tommy, the kid is a crybaby. And Takuya, he's a loudmouth, a hothead, and is sometimes more of a kid than Tommy, among other things.

Beliamon sighed tiredly as the pair rounded another corner.

"And you Kouji are insecure, self-consious, and unwilling to trust. That doesn't make you a bad person now does it? Nor does it make you a bad friend."

After that, the only sound within the Temple of Light's corridors were the sounds of footsteps and the quiet crackle of of Beliamon's sphere of fire.

"How would you know?" Kouji asked suddenly, breaking the silence, and in the dim light, Beliamon smiled to herself.

"Because I once had friends similar to yours. There was a girl, my best friend, a bit conceited, but she had a good heart. A loudmouth who got himself into trouble a lot, eveen with his best friend occasionally, but was loyal to all those he considered friends. A small one who knew little of the world and its cruelty, and was often victim of it, but continued to hope and live with a heart filled with with happiness on the days where the skies were a brilliant blue. And..." Beliamon trailed off suddenly. "I'm sorry...I'm rambling aren't I? We're almost to the kitchens. Then we can get you that snack."

"But they abandoned you, didn't they?" Kouji asked, an edge to his voice. "Your 'so-called' friends.

Siddenly, Beliamon stopped and the pair stood still in the hallway, their shadows on the walls dancing softly.

Slowly, Beliamon turned to Kouji, and he was surprised when she offered him a smile paired with a gaze that screamed of sorrow and ached with unshed tears.

"I'm afraid the opposite occured." she spoke quietly. "They died protecting me and this city. In the end, it was I that abandoned them."

And with that, Beliamon quickly resumed her walk towards the kitchens. For a few moments her footsteps were the only ones sounding before they were again joined by Kouji's. Both of them stayed silent from that point on, however.

***

Kouji was dodging left and right as Beliamon threw things from the cabinets in the kitchen with abandon, nearly getting hit in the head every few seconds.

Upon arriving to the kitchens, Beliamon had dissipated the somewhat stifled atmosphere they had incurred by cheerily asking him what he was in the mood for.

Caught off guard by her sudden mood swing, though he really shouldn't be by now, he had replied something sweet. In turn, his captor had begun haphazardly tossing things from shelves and cuphoards in her search.

"Now I KNOW I picked up candy! Cookies at least! Aha! Come to mama! Oh wait. No, that's a box of crackers. And this? What's this? This isn't even marked?" Beliamon muttered to herself as she chucked said items over her shoulder and nearly at Kouji.

Sighing heavily, she removed herself from the storage units and put her arms on her hips.

Turning to Kouji, she smiled cheesily.

"I guess I forgot where I put all the prepackaged stuff..." She said weakly and straightened herself. "I kinda planned on cooking your meals. And I didn't plan on many snacktimes."

Kouji rolled his eyes.

"You know, you really do that far too often." Beliamon noted.

"Yeah, yeah. What I don't understand is if you're job is to fatten me up, why don't you just do it? I'm pretty much defenseless you know." He remarked.

Beliamon sighed. He was full of questions tonight, that's for sure.

"Its...kind of complicated. As you know I work for Cherubimon who works for Lucemon...basically. I think. And Cherubimon commanded I...well, you know do what I'm doing. BUt I like what I'm doing. As in I like putting weight on digimon...er people. Things, let's just say things....no. Humanoid type digimon and now humans. But only to a certain extent That works. However, I don't like working for Cherubimon. In lamens terms, I'm doing something I like for somebody I don't like. But even if I didn't like what I'm doing, I'd be forced to do it. So I'm kind of a prisoner too. Sort of. Did that help?"

Kouji gave her a look and she sighed again.

"Mainly, know this: I'm not a bad guy, Kouji. If anything, I'm a pawn." She said tiredly, returning to rummaging for something sweet.

"Okay...so I'm your prisoner, and your Cherubimon's prisoner, making us both his prisoners. But since Cherubimon is working for Lucemon...and I'm just believing you on the premise he even exists..so we're REALLY...Lucemon's prisoners?" Kouji asked, unsure.

"Sounds good to me!" Beliamon exclaimed from her current spot within a walk-in cuphoard. "Grah! THat's it! I'm baking cookies! Forget finding the already made ones, for now at least."

"So...if we're BOTH prisoners..." Kouji mumbled to himself as Beliamon exited the cuphoard with materials for baking snickerdoodles in hand. "Why don't we both just leave?"

"Um...because Cherubimon would kill us? Well, kill you. Technically, I would be deleted. But that's basically being killed." Beliamon replied, setting her supplies down on an island counter.

"And...you DO know that the group I was apart of before you so visciously kidnapped me was working to get rid of Cherubimon, and I guess, ultimately Lucemon, right?" Kouji asked, coming over to her with a raised eyebrow.

"And...you DO know that Cherubimon would kill you and your little friends like the insignificant bugs at his feet you are, right? Plus, Lucemon could be revived at anytime. It took the power of ten Mega level digimon then, in addition to their followers, to only SEAL Lucemon. Now, half of the remains, well more than half, are in the hands of children, yes, children, while the other half have been corrupted by Cherubimon, and I hate to sound repetitive, but ultimately Lucemon. AND, the other two Great Angel Digimon, Serapimon and Ophanimon are currently indisposed, either due to deletion or imprisonment.

The look on Kouji's face told Beliamon that he was about to reply when he suddenly stopped and looked thoughtful.

"Mega level digimon?" He asked.

"See? You prove my point. Mega level is the highest level a digimon can reach to my knowledge."

"And you said we have more than half of the spirits. We have five, no more."

That caused Beliamon to freeze suddenly.

"Oh...my mistake. You're correct. Silly me." Beliamon said, inwardly cursing herself.

It wasn't time to play the Duskmon card, no, not quite yet.

Rolling his eyes, Kouji turned his attention to the pan Beliamon was getting out.

"Are you really going through all that trouble just to bake cookies? Just for me? In the middle of the night?" Kouji asked as if the answer was obvious.

"Well I do have the ingredients out don't I?" Beliamon asked in return before Kouji quickly grasper the pan away from her. "Well, do you wan't a snack or not?"

"I don't want you to have to bake THIS late!" Kouji shouted, putting the pan back into a cuphoard. "I really don't need a snack anyway..."

"Hmmm..." Beliamon mumured, thinking quickly. "Well...there is ONE more option. I could....magic the cookies up."

"Magic them up?" Kouji asked, looking both afraid and skeptical.

"Yes, well its not like "Poof!" and instant cookies. I make them by magic instead of by hand." Beliamon explained, gesturing to the ingredients. "There's only one catch...they can be very addicting and have many more calories than cookies I cook by hand. THis goes for all food I make by magic, really."

Upon hearing Beliamon's explanation, Kouji had first appeared wary, but to her delight, now looked only slightly afraid.

"Well...why not?" He finally replied.

Beliamon gave him a sideways look.

"Highly addictive." She reminded him, clucking her tongue.

"They can't be addictive if you only give them to me every so often. Its not like I can raid the kitchens for them." Kouji replied with a smirk.

Giving him another look, Beliamon finally smiled at her charge and shooed him a few feet away.

"I really should feed you at night more often. You seem to be more agreeable." She remarked.

Kouji gave her a flat look.

"Now, stay back. I'll be using fire to bake, of course."

Taking in a deep breath, Beliamon braced herself, holding her hands out before her and closing her eyes to concentrate. It had been a while since she had cooked food magically. Going over the recipe in her mind, Beliamon knew the show had started when she heard an intake of breath via Kouji.

In her mind's eye she saw the dish coming together, as if she was cooking by hand. In reality, the ingredients- water, eggs, flour, spices, and milk to name a few- were leaving there containing in swift motions and buzzing towards Beliamon's hand to create a wonderful cataclysm of a mixture. This she kept at for a few minutes until she felt the mixture was thourougly mixed. To add an extra fun touch, Beliamon then shaped the dough with her mind, making them into shapes.

'Now for the fun part.' she thought.

Opening her mouth ever slow slightly, Beliamon wished she could have seen the face to match Kouji's surprised yelp as a jet of flames was brought forth by blowing on the mixture gently. Again, this continued for a few minutes until Beliamon was satisfied that the snickerdoodles were cooked.

'And...done.' Beliamon thought, two cookies hovering in her palm as she did so. Blowing on them to cool them off, she then presented her masterpieces to Kouji.

His eye twitching, Kouji made a face at Belimaon as he examined one of the cookies.

"You made...me into a cookie...I don't know what to say." He muttered while Beliamon chuckled.

The cookie itself was rather embarassing: It showed himself now quite chubby, rubbing his stomach with a grin on his face.

The other cookie, also shaped like a person, he didn't know. It looked like him in a way, but something told him that it wasn't him. In addition to this, this cookie appeared sad and was also thin.

"WHo's this?" Kouji asked, but Beliamon had scampered off.

"All in due time, Kouji, all in due time. Now, let's go to bed! It may have been cooking by magic, but that's still cooking." She called from the door they had entered earlier.

"Um...sure." Kouji replied, looking down at his cookies awkwardly. "Beliamon, I'm sorry about earlier in the hallway. I shouldn't have acted the way I did about your friends."

Beliamon gave him a strnage look before giggling.

"Oh, don't apologize, Kouji. If anyone should apologize, it's me. Freaking out on you like that. I mean-"

"No." Beliamon was surprised at the firmness in Kouji's voice as he cut her off.

"No." Kouji repeated. "Beliamon...your friends..it's obvious that they meant a lot to you...more than the world. I shou;dn't have said what I said. And its make me think. The others...my friends..I think you're right about them."

This time Beliamon really did stare at Kouji before breaking into a genuine smile.

'He's coming out of his shell I think...at last.' She thought as Kouji returned her smile, albeit somewhat weaker, but just as real and as genuine as hers.

"Thank you Kouji." Beliamon said, winking as the boy walked over to her. "But really now, we need our sleep. OR at least you do. You're a growing boy after all.

Sighing at at Beliamon's joke, Kouji bit his head off, or rather, his cookie self's head. His eyes widened as he did so.

"These are really good!" He exclaimed and began munching on them posthaste.

Beliamon chuckled nervously, wondering if she had erred in giving Kouji magical food.

She did indeed want him to look like she had portrayed him in his cookie, but not if he lost all will and self control in the process.

Sighing, Beliamon straightened her gown.

In any case, right now the playing field was a bit sketchy. All they could do now was wait for the other pieces to move.

'Now things will be getting interesting.' Beliamon thought, the sounds of their footsteps joined now by the sound of Kouji munching.

'Perhaps I should have told him those two cookies are equal to a a dozen normal cookies each...oh well, don't want to ruin his apetite now.' Beliamon thought as the pair continued down the hallway on whatb would be their first night in Temple of Light.
