134122112112111122112212122111111221.content:
Kouji's mouth gradually widened into a lethargic yawn as he sleepily wandered his way through the once busy hallways of the Temple of Light.

A flow of relaxation passed through his body, but when that stopped he felt a rigidness somewhere in his back. Impulsively, Kouji slackly threw his arms up and nonchalantly stretched himself out, letting out a tired moan of relief. With that, his shirt may have ridden up at that point, exposing the slightest bit of his pale belly to the world, but he was too sluggish to notice.

The only partially wakeful wanderer ran a hand over his heavy eyelids as he trudged in the direction of two double doors, where he had heard all the ruckus of pots and pans clanging- that's where the blunette guessed, in his twilight state of thinking, it all must have been coming from.

With a push of the twin doors, or more accurately, a lunge of his body onto them, he recieved entry. The doors unfolded to reveal a large chamber covered with smooth or broken marble tables, with a chandeliers floating from a vaulted ceiling, suspended higher above Kouji than he was used to.

However, many of the details of this vast room became lost to him in his drowse. Plodding his way on inward, a wave of fragrance from the cookery wafted over to his senses, as well as the increased volume of the pots, pans, and utensils scraping vigorously away in the other room; both the sounds of cooking and a life other than his own in the Temple.

Briefly, he took a peek inside and saw Beliamon already busy. She been ready and waiting for him- already there was a big fire going, the stovetops flaring, and a stack of broken wood to use to feed the two.

Closing the door silently, so as not to attract attention, Kouji sauntered to the closest intact table. He was glad to see it was nice and smooth, just albeit a little worn over the centuries of usage. The Warrior of Light settled down, and collapsed softly on top of it, resting his head on top of a soft cushion made by his two arms.

He then closed his eyes, drifting back to resume the slumber that had been interrupted by his wristwatch minutes ago, that had. . . said he had. . . over. . . slept. . . and it was. . . time to. . .

* * *
A low sizzling had been hissing comfortably in the background.

And just then, a deep snicker sounded off in the darkness.

"Why, good morning, Kouji," an all too familiar voice spoke right within said boy's ear.

Half a second later, Kouji's eyes snapped open and he gasped deeply, as if he had just emerged from the watery depths of his own reveries.

Looking right back at him, sure enough, was Beliamon. As she caught sight of him, Kouji thought he saw some life and vitality restoring itself back into Beliamon's eyes, as well as a trademark smirk as she saw the state of her prisoner before her.

It must have been a long night, he inferred.

"Yeah, good morning t-"

Just then, Kouji stopped. His hands quickly darted up and started to feel the back of his head, patting it up and down.

The blunette let out a scowl of frustration, disheartenment, and maybe a little bit of embarassment. Said blue hair was now slack and flowing long and free down below his neck, a little awry and messy from his sleep. In his drowsings, he had forgotten to tie back his hair, and not to mention bandana!

On a second's notice, Kouji felt his back pocket, which seemed a smidgen smaller and tighter than ever before, for some odd reason. Luckily enough, not only was there was a rubber band handy but his trusty bandana, which he had completely neglected to tie over his head. Gathering these two all important relics in his hands, Kouji swiftly turned to a corner, and tied his hair back and his bandana across as fast as his hands could muster.

When he spun back to face Beliamon, he observed her smirk from before had developed even further. And when Kouji slightly blushed, thinking he had done a completely sloppy job, and hurried to make slight adjustments, she started to snicker.

"You're fine, trust me," Beliamon dismissed, waving her hand, "Anyway, your breakfast will be ready shortly. It's cooking on the stovetops right now. I'm sure you've brought the same appetite you had last night," she nodded and grinned, her eyes bright and wide awake.

Kouji just stared blankly at her for a moment.

". . . Ugh. . ." he grunted groggily, as he ran a hand through his bed head, or 'bench' head, "You're going to have to stop being so cheery and energetic in the morning," he moaned sarcastically, as he rubbed a sleepy eye, squinting at the auroral light of her sobering enthusiasm.

She masked her mouth briefly, concealing yet another abrupt chuckle, "Oh, I see. So did my so-called 'prisoner' get a good night's sleep?"

"Yeah, well, you know-" Kouji mumbled

Thinking to himself, sleeping was increasingly becoming a little harder to do. Even though the bench was comfy, his clothes were not, or at least they were getting that way. All the while, they were definitely getting all the smaller on him, and a little constricting to his reluctantly admittedly growing body. Using his jacket as a blanket, he had recently taken to just wearing his underclothes when he went to bed. Now he understood why pajamas existed in the first place.

"Not really, I guess I always could use a few more hours," he replied, before turning the question to his captor, "How about you?"

The sable clad captor shrugged, "Meh, hardly," she stated nonchalantly, her eyes darting to the side, as if recalling some sleepless hours. An exhausted tone flickered and translucently etched its way onto Beliamon's smiling face just briefly. Even her hair seemed slightly disheveled that moment. But it was not even a moment before it had already disappeared as fast as it had come.

A gaping expression of her prisoner's face brought back a chuckle to her lips.

"How!?" Kouji outbursted, astonished that his captor could even be. . . functioning at this hour 'hardly' sleeping. His eyes were at their widest since he woke up, "What? When exactly did you-"

Seeing Kouji's palid face, she simply sighed, lowered and shook her head and said, "Some nights I just have trouble getting some rest. It's nothing new. I'm thrilled more than anyone to say it's finally a new day, after all, and-"

Beliamon suddenly sniffed a disturbance in the air.

She was cut off by a trailing column of smoke emitting from the kitchen- to which she let out a bewildered yelp, and practically shot out of the room into the smoldering confines of the kitchen. She deftly pried the door open in a fell swoop to let fresh air pour in.

And before Kouji could even yell back much less get up and see whether everything was alright, the ardent scurrying and scraping of the kitchen returned, as well as an incredulous, "I can believe how these turned out! They're not completely charred at all, but I hope you like your sausages well-done, Kouji!"

Groaning inwardly, Kouji slid back into his seat, slouching before scrunching back up. With his head slack, he was given a perfect view of his paunch when sitting in such a manner, jutting out potently and ponderously over his lap as well as straining his yellow shirt considerably. He moved to give his soft midsection an idle poke, but it only made him yawn again.

"What time is it?" Kouji asked nobody in particular, as he picked his wrist up and read the green display of his light-up watch, "10:47?" he cried in disbelief, "How can that be right?"

If he had been in school, he might have been full of energy, ready to tackle a tricky math quiz at his desk right now, not nodding off at the breakfast table, waiting to be fed.

This had to be one of the most serious cases of jet lag he had ever experienced- or digital lag- or reality lag, or whatever it was, it was seriously messing around with his internal, biological clock.

Kouji remembered he thought his watch was broken when its alarm beeped irritatingly almost an hour ago, telling him he had overslept, disturbing his slumber. It felt like it was three, maybe four in the morning. But the alarm kept hammering its high pitched rings, and Kouji didn't want to get out, he didn't want to get up, and he was starting to get very, very ticked off.

Oddly, the joke about the boy throwing his clock out the window to see time fly had flashed through Kouji's crazed twilight state of mind.

So, Kouji had wandered, crossed the vestibule of the Temple, and meandered his way over to the cafeteria. . . when he peered into the kitchen, he had seen Beliamon tied up, thrusting skillets around an open flame and preparing what looked like eggs, stirring some kind of batter, and making a load of sausages to boot.

And, sure enough, a clatter sounded under his nose.

Right in front of him was a plate racked with a moderate amount of hot, steaming scrambled eggs next to a pile of waffles that must have been fresh from the iron with an odd number of sausages to a corner of the plate that were still sizzling.

And also, right before him was a Beliamon who was practically glowing.

Wordlessly, Beliamon rolled a cart over to Kouji's table as she quietly, and once again, selected a drink for him. After an antique, but thoroughly cleansed due to Beliamon's care, tankard had been filled with the thick, creamy milk from its enchanted jug, she tapped it and sent it levitating over to Kouji's lips for a sip.

Even though Kouji might have borne witness to several tricks like this before, his expression was still so incredulous and bug-eyed, it made Beliamon scoff up a few airy chuckles as an alarmed Kouji, now more than half awake for sure, tentatively downed some milk.

Beliamon transfered a set of silverware over to his which landed to his side, a napkin that descended to his lap, as well as a jug of maple syrup.

"Now, eat up," she beamed pleasantly, "After last night's request, I had a feeling that you'd be definitely hungry within a few hours notice. So dig in; it's not like you have to hide it from me this time"

Kouji responded with only a partially unexcited side glance, as he started to cut a bite sized piece out of the plump breakfast sausage, "Alright, alright, I'll try not to," he smirked sarcastically before popping it into his mouth and moving onto the next.

Just before he had cleared away the last of the sausages, Kouji saw Beliamon trailing back to the kitchen. A feeling of anxiety started to crawl in as he expected Beliamon was going to wheel in some huge monstrosity she had been working away at for him to devour. . . or worse.

"Uhm," Kouji started, "You wouldn't happen to have something else in there, like, you know. . ." he gulped before uttering the word, "Seconds?"

"Hmm?" Beliamon spun around before she stated, "No- I'm just about to fix up something for myself. Digimon's got to eat too. We can't just live off air alone, you know."

Especially after last night's excursion and sleep, or lack thereof, she did need all the energy she could get, despite how well she could conceal this.

"-Why, do you want me make some more for you, Kouji?" she implored eagerly.

"Oh no, no, I'm fine!" he cried, an outrageously wide smile ripped across his face and he held his hands up, waving them rapidly in defense.

"If you say so," Beliamon nodded, heading off into the kitchen to make her own breakfast.

As the clattering of the kitchen came back to life, Kouji proceeded to clear through the delicious yellow folds of the scrambled eggs. At first, he was eating at a leisurely pace, but the warmth and flavor he experienced compelled him to move from a casual ladle to a hurried yet impassioned scoop and even to a ferverous shovel.

Hearing the shuffle of silverware in the background among the rattling of her own kitchenware prompted a smile from his captor in the kitchen.

Still cooking, over her shoulder, Beliamon called out, "I hope you're not shy with that maple syrup as well."

An irritated scowl filled the room in response to her quip. Any giggling on her part was completely concealed by the shifting of pots and pans.

Well, thought Kouji, it's not like she's watching me or anything. He let out a guilty sigh as his hand moved toward the jug of maple syrup and let it pour loose over the golden brown waffles. As he savored the sweet and light texture of said waffles, he also tried to scoff them up to prevent his captor from seeing he had so willingly resorted to such a notion.

Beliamon set aside what she had been cooking and scurried with some sort of tray.

"My breakfast's still cooking, but I still have time to spare," she explained as she set it down on the table, "Here," she indicated the tray, "I hope you like watermelon."

To her surprise, Kouji didn't seem as opposed to the idea as she had anticipated. He just shrugged and actually took a slice or two onto his plate as he finished off the last waffle.

After he was done chewing, swallowing, and downing the respective mouthfuls of milk to wash it all down, Kouji let out a sigh of relief.

Beliamon just watched him attentively, as if scrutinously observing the mean amount of rotations his disappearing jawline went through per minute. As soon as he caught on, he blanched, and just leaned forward, staring back at her in return, somewhat mortified. In reaction, Beliamon burst into laughter, and a still mortified Kouji now leaned backwards, contemplating once again her sanity.

An awkward moment passed.

Kouji went placidly silent. He cleared his throat and opened his mouth, like he was about to say something, but no words came out. His lips promptly shut, hesitation etched all over his face.

"What is it, Kouji?"

"I just have to say. . ."

The blunette's eyes veered off to the side as he paused again, looking as if he were struggling with possible consequences of what might come with he was about to remark on. . .

"This is really delicious," Kouji admitted softly, looking down, "You're really a wonderful. . . cook. Did you know that?" he asked.

"Thank you, Kouji," she said, looking at him sincerely, "I know all too well, unfortunately," Beliamon remarked a bit morosely, "Anyway, I suppose it's always bit a bit of a hobby for myself."

A foolish grin spread across Kouji's face, as he let out a chuckle, "Heh, I remember the last time I tried to cook. We were all in some competition to make a better hamburger than each other."

His eyes returning to Beliamon took on a softer tone as well as his voice which sheepishly admitted, "I tried to make a squid burger or something like that."

This won an astonished eyebrow arch from Beliamon.

In response, Kouji blushed and continued, "Well, Takuya's was much worse. That blockhead had no idea what he was doing. I swear just the look of whatever he had the courage to call a hamburger made me want to puke!"

"That's kind of rough for someone who 'oh-so-desperately' wishes to be reunited with his fellow comrades," she chided playfully, clasping her hands together dramatically before she started laughing again.

"Yeah, well," Kouji started, "We're guys, you know? Sometimes we like to mess around with each other like that," he smirked.

Beliamon stopped and gazed, as if some truth she knew all too well had struck once more. She nodded in an almost dreamlike affirmation.

1341221121121111221122121221111112212.content:
Chewing off the scant few remains of fruit that remained on his second piece of watermelon, Kouji sighed, and Beliamon gave him a sidelong glance.

It wasn't a sigh of satisfaction, she had noticed, as the blunette licked the remaining syrup off of his fork before sitting it down on the marble table with a clack.

"...You know...I miss them. I actually miss them." He said, after a small silence, looking at Beliamon with eyes that doubted his own words.

Offering, him a small, sad smile, Beliamon quickly gathered the remains of his breakfast and placed them on the cart.

"I knew that you did. You're not as cold as you'd like to think, Kouji." She replied as she wheeled the cart back into the kitchen to deposit the dishes.

Chuckling to himself, Kouji stretched once more, shaking the remaining feelings of sleep off, and propped his elbows up on the marble table, his heard resting in his hands, as he waited for Beliamon to return.

"So...you say that they're going through the same...process...that you're putting me through?" Kouji called offhandedly as he glanced down at the belly he still wasn't quite used to seeing pooled in his lap.

"Mhhm." Beliamon shouted from her place in the kitchen as she left the dirty dishes in a basin to soak and simply incinerating the watermelong husks with a few small jets of flame via her magic, depositing what dust that was left into a small wastebin.

"That's a rather nondescript answer from you." Kouji said sarcastically as Beliamon walked back to the table where Kouji was seated at and took a seat herself.

Beliamon shrugged as she brushed some of her blonde hair out of her face.

"Comapred to our situation, their own IS a rather nondescript one." She replied. "To put it simply, they're still in the meat apple grove I retrieved you from, though...I suppose a few variables have changed since then."

"And those variables are?" Kouji asked, raising an eyebrow suspiciously at Beliamon.

"Well...you know how Ayzahn Ra and what remains of the Temples are basically islands floating in a sea of nothingness, right?"

Kouji nodded.

"Since then, the meat apple grove at which you and your friends were camped has become a similar place, though not to such an extreme degree as that of Ayzahn Ra. Furthermore, the trees there have been hydrophonically enhanced to produce larger and richer meat apples by Ranamon."

"And they havn't figured it out yet?" Kouji asked, incredulous. "They havn't wondered where I'VE been?"

Chuckling slightly, Beliamon nodded.

"Oh yes they've wondered. But they've been distracted not only by the larger meat apples but also by the fact that..." Beliamon coughed here. "But also by the fact that someone sent them a message on your digivice poing as you and telling them that you would be back in a few days..."

Kouji stared at Beliamon for a few moments before giving her a very flat look.

"Oh, I wonder who that could have been?" He asked dourly.

"Who's to know?" Beliamon asked brightly before giglling awkwardly.

Composing herself, she then gave Kouji a professional look as she crossed her arms.

"Since then, their weight has been increasing at an admirable pace and they've been carefully watched over by Ranamon and Mercurymon, though the girl- Zoe is it?- seems to be realizing that something isn't right."

At that, Kouji brightened, but not for the reason Beliamon had thought.

"So then I'm NOT the only one getting fatter! Ha!" He shouted jubilantly, standing up and striking their aire with a fist. "Heh, at least Takuya won't be able to talk when I finally see him again."

Giggling, Beliamon nodded as she reached over and quickly grabbed a part of Kouji's paunch that had been revealed when he had stood up so hastily.

"Yeah, he's made a lot of progress. They all have. More than you actually. You have some catching up to do." Beliamon said giddily ad Kouji blushed and smacked her hand away before resuming his sitting position with a huff.

"Progress, my foot." Kouji scoffed. "You mean to tell me that they all weigh more than me now?"

"Please, of course not. The girl and the child are lighter than you of course and the one big guy, he weighed more than you from the start. I was referring to the speed at which they were gaining weight." Beliamon explained as she massged her temples. "Up until recently, you were far more reluctant to eat than they were."

"Oh...well that makes sense I guess. Takuya and J.P love food, always have. And Tommy, he's a kid. He'd probably prefer candy but I guess meat apples work too. And Zoe...well I guess the pounds have to add up sometime." Kouji said simply as he turned his head up to look at the decrepit marble ceiling.

Sighing heavily, Beliamon stood up and looked around the cafeteria herself.

Impressive upon seeing them for the first time, much of what remained of the Temple of Light made her feel like she was in a mausoleum. The white, worn structures and furniture, much of it destroyed and lying in heaps of rubble here and there, coupled with the musty smell of powdered marble and emptiness, made her feel like she was stuck in a decrepit world, void of color.

"This place must have been so much more beautiful when everything wasn't broken and light was streaming through the windows..." Beliamon muttered offhandedly, suddenly finding herself feeling very stifled and bored.

Next to her, Kouji yawned.

"I guess I'm still a bit sleepy after all." He said as he rested his head on the table again, as he had done before Breakfast.

Her eye ticking, Beliamon quickly yanked Kouji up and began to drag him off down a corridor.

"Hey! What's the big deal? Where are we going?" Kouji asked as he finally managed to free his shirt from Beliamon's grip.

"I don't know. Somewhere. Out into the fresh...well...out into the air that's at least not as stale as the air in here."

Stopping quickly, with a flick of her wrist the cart she had used earlier raced to her side with a speed that should have broken it's wheels, now fully loaded with pre-packaged snacks and drinks that Beliamon had apparently found.

***

Kouji's steps and the sounds of the cart rolling along magically behind her, Beliamon breathed in deeply as she finally emerged on the steps leading up to the once hidden portion of the Temple of Light.

It wasn't that much better outside.

Her shoulders sagging, Beliamon sighed as she looked out over the portion of the city she could see from here.

"I at least wish that the sky was blue." She said, mostly to herself. "If the sky could be blue, if I could see the sun, the moons, and the stars from here, if the air could be fresh."

Kouji stepped up to where she had stopped on the steps and looked at her concernedly.

She was acting odd again. He hoped she didn't go into one of her fits.

"But no," Beliamon was still ranting. "The air is thick with dilapidation and the lack of life. Night and Day are just two shades of gray. Neither the sun nor the moon has shined on this city in ages."

"Beliamon?" Kouji ventured carefully.

Beliamon didn't respond for a few long seconds, but finally sighed, and turned to Kouji, eyes closed and smiling slightly, repressing the feelings that had threatened to overwhelm her.

"Sorry." She replied simpy. "I giess...I guess this city is starting to get to me. The emptiness, the lack of color, the...lack of life."

Looking at her now, Kouji's jaw suddenly dropped, his eyes trained on the skin between her chest and her neck.

Following his gaze, Beliamon was shocked herself, that upon glancing down at where Kouji was looking, she found a symbol, seemingly burned into her skin.

"What's...this?" She asked, gingerly reaching out to touch the scar. To her relief, it did not hurt, not even in the slightest.

"That's the symbol of Light." Kouji responded, studying it closely. "It looks almost like a tattoo. It must have happened when that beam of light shot out from your chest yesterday and revealed the Temple of Light...or what's left of it at least. I must have been to groggy earlier to notice it."

Beliamon winced at the memory, taking her hand away from the scar.

"Speaking of that...how exactly did that happen?" Kouji asked as Beliamon again looked out over the city. "You obviously didn't cause it. Not willingly at least."

Beliamon gave Kouji a look and then giggled.

"I guess the secret's out of the bag, finally." She saidas she began walking down the steps, the cart slowly following her so as to prevent it from falling over. "You're correct. I didn't summon the beam of light yesterday that revealed the Temple of Light. On the contrary, it was you. Or your digivice rather."

"My...digivice?" Kouji asked, a third confused, a third disbelieving, and a third astounded. "That beam of light came from within you...which means that my digivice-"

"Is inside me." Beliamon finished as she again touched the scar on her chest. "Its nothing that extraordinary, really. I specialize in the power of Darkness, so I reached into myself and placed it in one of the folds of darkness that lies around my soul...if you can say digimon have a soul that is."

"That's...how will I ever get it back then?" Kouji asked as he stumbled to catch up to Beliamon, now at the bottom of the steps.

"Either when I give it back to you, which may be never, or...when I am deleted, which truthfully, could be at any time." Beliamon responded phrophetically and the two walked in silence for a while.

'Obviously, Kouji is thinking of ways to retrieve his digivice.' Beliamon though, smiling at how she had come to know his mind worked in such a short amount of time. Perhaps it was because they were, in some ways, similar.

"But...my digivce is empowered with my Human and Beast spirits, both of whom are Light digmon. Wouldn't having them inside of you hurt?" Kouji asked with real concern in his voice.

"Hmm...it never hurt until yesterday," Beliamon replied, taking a different road other than the avenue they had walked the other day. "Before that, it always felt like the soft glow of a candle or the winking of stars on a moonless night. The other day, it felt like it...like it was eating away at me."

"Hmm...and you still want to carry it within you?" Kouji questioned.

"I have no choice. I can't let you have it, not yet at least. Right now, its hidden where the only way it can be taken forcefully is if I die. And not to brag but, short of Cherubimon and a few select Mega level digimon, I'm pretty powerful." Beliamon replied as she tried to match up any of buildings they were passing now with her bearings from the Ayzahn Ra of the past.

"Ah, I believe if we keep heading in this direction we'll reach a crossroads that leads to the Temple of Wood and the Temple of Water- or what remains of them at least, if anything." Beliamon said as she noticed the buildings get smaller.

"The Water and Wood Temples?" Kouji prompted.

"I know for a fact that the majority of the land the temples were housed on and most if not all of the temples themselves were deleted, but both the Water and Wood Temple had very beautiful grounds dedicated to them, and as far as surface area goes, they were two of the largest." Beliamon said as the pair past the last buildings on the street and the street became a path that wound its way over to the edge of the makeshift island Ayzahn Ra was situated upon.

Glancing over the edge into the gray abyss, Beliamon moved a few steps away from the perilous drop.

"And be careful here, Kouji. With the weight you've gained recently your center of balance is bound to be off and this path may be littered with debris. If you trip and fall into the abyss don't say I didn't warn you." Beliamon half taunted.

"Ha. Ha. Ha. You're so funny." Kouji retorted but nonetheless followed Beliamon's example of moving away from the abyss. "So, what did these two Temples look like?"

Sighing dreamily, Beliamon stopped for a moment and got her bearing once more.

"Both were very beautiful, like all temples, but unlike the others, their beaughty was found equally in nature as it was in their structures." Beliamon stated.

"The Temple of Wood was, of course, made of wood, and most of the buildings were small, but they were all very...elegant? No, that's not the word. They were'nt as..proper I suppose. Some were built on top of tress, others were normal buildings on the ground, some were built into trees themselves. Some of the professors didn't even use rooms! Instead they just used plazas or gardens. Most of the cafeterias were like this too, stone benches and tables, flowers everywhere, and these streams fed by the Temple of Water. All the outdoor areas were magicked with invisible shields to keep bad weather out, not that there was that often in the Temple of Wood." Beliamon said euphorically, breathing in as if to remember the scent of it all. "It was like a giant garden eternally in bloom. Of course, it did have it's central building. The Living Tree it was called. A giant tree in the center of the Temple of Wood, with rooms inside it and outside it and in its branches. Hewn out but still alive. It was all so beautiful."

"Unlike most of the other Temples, the Wood and Water Temples were open to most all residents of Ayzahn Ra. They not only served as places of learning but recreation areas as well. And oh, I've only explained the Temple of Wood." Beliamon stated, and Kouji could tell she was enraptured in her memories.

"The Temple of Water was as beautiful as the Temple of Wood was, but it also had a mystical sense about it. Giant shells, suspended by magic high above the Temple of Water were contuously gushing water down into the Temple, you see from the Temple of Water was esentially a giant lake with lake with islands and buildings scattered throughout it, and the sound of running water was always heard. And the buildings seemed to just rise up out of the water and were made of the deep, brown-gray stone covered by ivy and all of these green plants and some were underwater alltogether! Water lillies and a rainbow of different colored flowers grew on the lake or
under the surface of it. Coral, you humans call it? The water was so clear that you could always see to the bottom and giant trees grew right out up out of the water and cast shade so that when the sun was shining, everything was in beautiful contrast...the central building of the Water Temple was this castle made out of the same stone as the lake floor and most of it was underwater, you had to swim to enter it actually, and the spires of the castle rose up out of the water and water fell from openings in the spires just like the shells...Ikaku Castle I think it was called. And I was told that most of the interior was actually dry...and I could tell you more but I've ranted so much already." Beliamon ended breathlessly.

"Wow...they both sound so beautiful..." Kouji responded, lost in Beliamon's descriptions.

"They were. It was a great loss for Ayzahn Ra when they were destroyed." Beliamon replied and sighed but birghtened. "But there might just be something left. Just a small remnant of their former glory."

Kouji, reaching for a few cookies on the cart that had loyally followed Beliamon and making himself a nice snack, had a hopeful look in his eyes.

"I hope so. I'd like to see what they might have been like, even if its nowhere near how they used to look" He responded.

"Well then," Beliamon said as she turned to Kouji with her hands on her hips, noticing in delight that he was snacking, "We have a decision to make."

And Kouji saw that they had reached the crossroads Beliamon had spoken of.

"If we want to check out the Temple of Wood, we should take the left path. If we want to head over to the Temple of Water we need to keep on this path as it curves around to the other side of the island." Beliamon stated and gestured to both paths clearly. "I don't really care which one we check out. Would you rather see one or the other, Kouji?"

Thinking it over for a moment, Kouji opened his mouth to say...

13412211211211112211221212211111122122.content:
In Cherubimon’s lair, just hours after the western rebellions, as well as thousands of lives, had been single-handedly silenced, the dejected culprit named Duskmon was morosely haunting the dark corner he had always resided in, yet at that very moment, he was even more lost within the obscurity of darkness itself than he had been ever before.

Despite all the chaos and screaming he had both conjured up and crushed down, none of it so much as pierced his blackened, calloused helmet of a skull, or went on to clang and echo against its cast iron edges and torment him so as did that solitary damned name that fidgety young witch had so casually infected him with.

The scene replayed for the thousandth time in his mind, “Well, it was nice talking to you… Kouichi!” she exclaimed, the glint in her eyes growing like wildfire as she stared straight through him. Even though he was facing a stone wall the next moment, the moment had him frozen for minutes on end.

“Kou…ichi?” he had uttered to himself in sheer bewilderment and confusion.

He heard a drip of water fall in the distance. No, that name she had called him, Kouichi, had resounded within him too much to simply be misplaced. The mere fact that something as trivial as a name chilled and inflicted this degree of distress on the most heartless of the Dark Warriors signified its sheer magnitude. It threatened to slowly tear apart the ruthless confidence and fortitude that what he once knew he had, bit by bit. But what did it mean?

Could he truly be Kouichi?

Or was this some kind of treacherous spell placed on him by that capricious Beliamon to render him insane? Could that be an attempt to impede him from resuming his watch over her upon his return? He had more than mere suspicions toward her loyalties anyway. At face value, she might just be identified as an evil Digimon… but maybe that’s why Cherubimon chose her though.

Regardless, he deeply desired to resume his vigil over her to ensure the source of his bewilderment wasn’t trying to pull something while he was away on duty. He soon got his wish.

***

“Heeellllllooo?” Kouji boomed down the tremendous chasm only to find no echo. Not satisfied, he took a deep breath and prepared to thunder as loud as he could. Beliamon covered his mouth from behind before he could.

“Ah, ah, ah,” she chided, “That’s enough. The enormous basin might look like a huge endless canyon, but it empties into the vast nothingness below. Yet, for some reason, your voice is sucked into the huge vacuum of the abyss before it can hit its own distant sides and bounce back to your ears.”

Kouji exhaled and blushed a little, “Yeah, I guess it’s pointless to try.”

“Although,” Beliamon continued, as if having omitted his last statement, “if your body was hurdling down the void with what’s left of the earth rushing past you, I bet your voice would bounce back, so the last thing you would ever hear in this world would be your dying screams as you vanished into nothing.”

Kouji blinked and returned a bleak expression to her, “… Wow, that was pretty morbid.”

Beliamon nodded delightfully before cracking up, “I didn’t scare you, did I?”

“No!” Kouji exclaimed, maybe a little too loudly for his own interests.

“Now don’t you get any ideas, I can’t have any prisoner of mine dying on me,” she stated as Kouji turned pale, “Well, on second thought,” she reconsidered, placing a finger on her lip, “Cherubimon probably wouldn’t mind one dead Digidestined. Oh! In fact, that might be exactly what he’s trying to do!” she exclaimed with a loud flourish.

“… gee, ya think?” Kouji grumbled.

“So if you feel compelled to suddenly end your misery, feel free to go ahead and take the plunge. Oh, but do remember to go in head first. That way you can hear your final cries in this world…”

…

An awkward silence followed, only to be broken up by some modest chuckling. But any chortling from either party was soon dissipated by the awe elicited by the sheer presence of the magnificent gulf before them; the main basin was like an extremely wide and voluminous crater which extended into the distance and plunged down miles and miles, possibly down to the endlessness of the abyss itself.

Beliamon whistled, taking in the desolation’s depth.

Kouji nodded, biting into yet another soft, perpetually warm cookie, much to Beliamon’s delight. He had yet to catch onto the fact that these cookies had also been magicked up, just as the ones he had eaten last night were, she thought. No wonder he was eating them so early in the day- he wouldn’t be satisfied at least until he had gobbled a quite a few, just to sate the effects, but that was a limit he had well crossed several times over.

Beliamon sauntered up a steep hill, worn smooth by the course of time. At its summit, she parked herself and motioned for Kouji to join her, “There’s a better view up here,” she called.

Once he did so, the blunette gazed down in marvel. The foot of the hill emptied directly into the chasm revealing nothing but vast, dull, sandy plains of the once lakebed that extended broadly from the dimensions below to the gray horizons above. Many parts of the bed lay far and deep in the distance and were soon obscured by the gray mists of the horizon, opening up into the very abyss itself.

Kouji thought he could make out some tiny, worn, gray ruins upon the curved banks of the once glorious body of water. As his eyes meandered off to the side, he spotted a solitary, worn down, outlandish looking tower awkwardly wobbling on its last, malformed leg. He gasped after squinting for a better look. Remnants of various buildings, towers, and castles were scattered like dried bones across what surface area of the lake floor that Kouji could see.

“That’s all that remains of the Temple of Water,” Beliamon said sorrowfully, “It really was a sight to see, especially on warm summer nights when the full moon sank down to shine off the calm waters of the lake,” As she described, her eyes seemed to take in a glint of moonlight.

Several wide peaks extended their way near the upper heights, their summits taking on a lighter gray tone than its once submerged underbelly.

“They may look like lonely mountains right now,” Beliamon shook her head, “But they had once existed as lush islands, and also as some favorite retreat locations for Ayzahn Ra students of all extractions and varieties. The whole reason why some even bothered studying seriously was so that they could get a dream cabin there and meet new people over vacation- I heard it was quite an experience.”

“Did you ever stay on one of those islands?” Kouji inquired offhandedly.

“Oh no,” Beliamon shook her head, “I only hoped like everyone else. Plus, I never really got around to being a full time student, remember? But I can only imagine what those summer nights must have been like there… That’s not to say it was boring to stay in the city; every day was vibrant, and there always were a lot of things going on, especially during the summer,” Beliamon recollected, blinking.

“Like what?”

“Oh, you know- there’s always the summer festival of course. Many places hold celebrations on the first week of summer, but in Ayzahn Ra, everything always seemed larger than life. Then, at the end of summer was the weeklong city festival, which concluded with the Marathon on the last day of summer. Many raced a course spanning in and around the city, yet I really only saw it once… the whole thing that is,” Beliamon coughed, “I, myself, er, knew someone who entered quite well-”

“Hmm?” went Kouji.

Her eyes slid towards Kouji’s, “His name was…”

Beliamon went quiet as her lips curled into a bitter smile. Suddenly, her chest panged. It was starting to act up again. Her energy drained and color fled from her eyes, becoming as gray and still as everything else in the dead city. She began to feel as light as driftwood, pushed by the waves and floating away.

Then she doubled over and fell to the ground, her limp body steadily sliding down the hillside toward the neverending abyss.

Without a second thought, Kouji sprang to his feet and leapt after her, dashing to the edge before she got there, “Beliamon!” he yelped, hopefully prying her consciousness out of its current paralyzed state. Much to his chagrin, he couldn’t speed his way down the hill as fast as he used to, but much to his relief, he still made it to the bottom in time- as soon as he had held her arm tight, her legs slid over and dangled before the great emptiness.

“Come on Beliamon!” Kouji yelled, crying her name out repeatedly as he struggled to lift her out, pulling her lower half out of danger and onto firm ground. Soon he had moved her a few yards away from falling and placed her flat so she wouldn’t start spinning toward the chasm again.

“Damn, she’s spaced out again,” he cursed, remembering what had happened to her the night before... but that aside he didn’t know much more. Kouji tried to take her pulse, if she even had one to begin with- and he didn’t see anything to worry about. She seemed to be breathing fine… it had to be that his Digivice and Spirits imbedded within her were causing her pain. He couldn’t remove them on his own. She definitely needed to lie down somewhere for a while, but just somewhere that wasn’t dangerously close to a bottomless pit.

He rested Beliamon’s motionless arm on his shoulder and bended his knees, slowly trying to rise with her. Pushing up with his legs, he struggled but nonetheless lifted his captor and began climbing up the steep hillside, taking the utmost care not to make the slightest misstep. Every single one had to be taken with complete caution… every one calm, every one strong. His eyes looked above to the hilltop, his goal, where he could ascertain his goal and be filled with hope once understanding how close it was.

But Kouji was not filled with hope at what he saw. He turned pale, eyes widening with despair, posture suddenly slackening to dangerous angles, feet starting to slip in due time.

A single black figure starkly loomed over the peak amidst the pale grayness, waiting.

Duskmon.
