14.title: Dreams

choices: In a dark room with only one light, strapped to a chair...
In a laboratory, designed for research and development...
141.content:
It is, as with all great spy stories, a dark night. Not a sound is heard anywhere in the world at all, and a peaceful silence lays itself over the Earth like a warm blanket; offering its warmth and security. But, to you, it's too quiet.

Underneath this blanket, there are some nasty bed bugs. And you, Takuya, are the only one capable of removing every last one of them.

You are currently on a stake out mission. Nothing special, they told you back at HQ. Just walk about, scope things out, and report back. With a mission so simplistic, what's the point in providing you anything special?

They've taken everything but your gun, leaving you with your instincts and clothes to walk up and down a few lonely street blocks.

No need for fancy clothes. You're stuck in the standard spy trench coat, but underneath you're only wearing a pair of jeans and a shirt. What? Not like you're going to run into anyone who you'd want to take it off of you.

"Darn it all... I'm better than this." You scoff, kicking at the curb of the street you're currently walking on. "Danger! Excitement! Where are they? Where are the reasons I joined this organization?" You sigh, clearly frustrated with the world.

Minutes later, you stop on a dark street corner. Well, dark minus the street light you're standing under. The light has a yellowish color, adding a splash of liveliness to the sides of the low-class buildings within view. You snort disapprovingly, thinking that your time would be better spent at home sleeping than actually walking around on the curb. You feel useless.

Little does your dream self know, that Cherubimon's magic is beginning its work on your dream...

You sigh and look around. Amused yet again by the tints of yellow on the dingy building walls. Suddenly, out of the darkness behind you, a hand reaches out and covers your mouth and nose. In panic, you inhale deeply, hands grasping the hand with both of your own trying desperately to pull it away.

The fumes are intoxicating, and quickly your struggles fade into unconsciousness as the world around you blackness. The warm blanket has wrapped itself around you and strangled you, leaving you to fend for your own.

You wake up later...
141.title: Not safe alone...

1412.content:
Takuya groaned as he found himself groggy and strapped tightly to a chair. It was pretty dark in the room, and the only light was in the center of the room. It was so bright, Takuya had to squint when looking up to it- it illuminated even the dust in the air.

Suddenly, big, heavy footsteps sounded from a metal staircase landing... the feet thundered against the steel as it vibrated and reverberated around the room.

Takuya began to sweat as he knew someone was coming for him... Takuya, world class international spy wouldn't stand for this- he couldn't allow himself to be taken so easily by a scientist or whoever was there in the dark laboratory he was being held in...

Quickly, he got out his laser pen, and-

***

"Today's the day!" screamed an overly excited voice accompanied by the pattering of small bare feet on wooden floors that woke Takuya up. Rustling around in his bedsheets, Takuya stirred, grumbled, and groaned as he was still groggy and had just been woken up.

He rubbed his eyes, still in sleep mode before allowing the gears in his mind some time to catch up. Technically, he was still half-asleep, but he never really expected that he would get to sleep in today.

"...that was a weird dream," he mumbled to himself, "but it ended towards the good part..." Still growling to himself, a little upset and still tired, he rolled out of bed, still in his boxers and t-shirt and opened up the bedroom door.

Sure enough, there was his little brother, Shinya, parading all over the house, skipping and jumping for joy. Why?

"Because today's my BIRTHDAY! Yippee!" Takuya's hyped little brother yelped as he skipped around looking like he was about to do a cartwheel in his orange pajamas.

Takuya peered around as quick as he could, observing to see if anyone else was home before Shinya could notice he was actually awake.

Nope, not a soul. It's worse than he feared. His dad was off at work and his mom had already gotten up very early in the morning to do some last minute shopping for her oh-so-special birthday boy. Probably there would be a note or something left by his mom around the area of the refrigerator.

Takuya sighed as he rested his cheek in his hands. Why didn't he ever get the big birthday celebrations. Being nine isn't really all it's cracked up to be...

But there was no way he could tell that to his blissful brother, who, at this moment, could be found scrambling over to his older brother as fast as he could, a wide and devious grin on his face.

"Guess what, Takuya?" Shinya eagerly implored. Takuya could see where this was going.

"What?" he whined unenthusiastically.

"It's my BIRTHDAY!" Shinya yelled, leaping in the air, almost falling out of his pajamas, "And yooou know what that means..." he said with a sparkling grin on his face, his eyes sparkling with no good intentions.

"You're another year older?" Takuya yawned, scratching his belly sluggishly.

Shinya looked a little taken aback, "Well, yeah, but that's not so important-" Shinya recovered as he cried, "Since it's my birthday, it means I get what I want!" He then started giggling wildly with a wide, mischievious grin plastered all over his face.

No wonder he felt so happy. Shinya felt that because it was his birthday, he had acquired absolute power over everyone else for a single day. No wonder he felt so happy, and no wonder small children enjoy birthdays so much, if not for all the presents.

"Isn't that kinda beside the point?" Takuya asked, slouching against the door to his bedroom, which he had closed at this point.

"Hey!" Shinya yelled, "Shut up! It's my birthday!" he implied again, in the case that Takuya had forgotten the other seven hundred and thirty-six times he had been told this before.

"Yeah, alright," Takuya muttered as he started to walk down the hallway, his younger brother's feet scuttering behind his as he tried to overtake his pace and beat him to the kitchen. To be honest, Takuya loved Shinya as much as anyone else would love their younger brother, but he seriously felt that he could be such an arrogant brat most of the time.

"Are you sure you don't know where Mom hid my presents?" Shinya implored.

"For the last time, NO, already!" Takuya snapped, spinning around, giving him an angry look, almost raising his voice against his younger brother. He stopped himself, though- he was actually going to make an effort to get his brother to enjoy the day, even if it meant him losing half his sanity.

"Hmm... she must be out buying them," Shinya contemplated, putting his hands on his waist, "I'm gonna call her and tell her not to get me anything stupid. Like clothes."

Takuya tried not to respond to that, but he wouldn't let his little brother do such a thing. Luckily, both their attentions soon became fixed on a great spectacle to behold, sitting and taking up most of the kitchen table.

"That's the biggest birthday cake I've ever seen in my life!" Takuya exclaimed, pointing at the behemoth of a pastry. Shinya's mouth lay slack in pure surprise and his eyes sparkled with happiness as he brought both his hands together.

To be frank and brief, the cake could easily compare to or even overshadow a wedding cake. It was a beautiful chocolate masterpiece, standing firm about three to five layers tall. It didn't sway over to one side because it was of a stocky build and stood perfectly wide and tall.

The entire cake was covered evenly and perfectly smooth with a velvety chocolate ganache frosting. On the border of each layer was a white frosting ring, with flowers cast of icing sprouting out at random points. At the very top of the cake was a thick ring that looked like a green leaf crown with flowers all about. Its surface read, 'Happy 9th Birthday, Shinya! We love you!' in delicious looking yellow frosting.

"Aren't parents supposed to love the older siblings best?" Takuya asked, scratching his head in confusion. Shinya smacked him upon hearing that, but continued to gaze upon his marvelous cake.

It didn't make sense at all. All Takuya got for HIS 9th birthday was a few cupcakes. Maybe it was because Shinya got better grades than him, but what serious grades can you get when you're nine? He still is pretty dumb, thought Takuya. Shinya sucked up a lot to Mom and Dad, though, even though he was horribly behaved around his older brother.

'Maybe Dad got a really big bonus...' thought Takuya. He noticed that there was a note his mom left desecreetly on the refrigerator, just as he expected. He skimmed over it while Shinya was still looking at his cake.

To sum it all up, it said that she was out getting Shinya presents. She hadn't bought them yet because she knew that if she bought them before directly giving them to him, Shinya would find them somehow. She said she had picked up the cake very early in the morning and she would be back with his dad, who was able to leave work early (maybe when his boss heard that Shinya was having a party, he decided to give his dad a bonus) to celebrate the party together. It also said to make Shinya happy, help him have fun on his special day, and that she loved them both (although Takuya could have sworn Shinya's name was written slightly larger than his).

Takuya sighed as his brother was complaining again, "When's breakfast?" he whined.

"Whenever you feel like it, birthday boy," Takuya said sweetly, his teeth gritting together a little too hard.

"Well, make me something good for breakfast," Shinya smirked, "Let's try not to have another accident like the eggs and bacon cereal."

"Hey, you're the one who came up with the idea, I merely cooked it," Takuya protested, "But this time, I'll cook something I know how to. How about rice?"

Shinya looked like he had just whiffed a skunk, "Rice? Are you kidding me?"

"Well, how about toast?"

"... Do you even know how to cook anything good, Takuya?" Shinya asked.

"What do you think?" Takuya snapped, getting a little frustrated, "But as a final option, I can offer you waffles, but we're out of syrup."

"... You don't know how sad I am on my birthday, and I haven't even been awake for an hour," Shinya sniffled, trying to win Takuya's sympathy. Instead of feeling sorry, Takuya felt about ready to wring his brother's neck.

"Okaaay..." he sighed, "What do you want then?"

"Hmm, good question," Shinya agreed, not even knowing what he wanted for breakfast.

"Good! Toast it is!" Takuya exclaimed, half-hoping he wouldn't fry himself in the process.

Seven minutes passed...

A black pile of ashes was smoking on the plate Takuya placed in front of Shinya, "Mmm! Doesn't that look delicious, Shinya?" Takuya exclaimed.

Shinya stared down nervously at the plate in front of him as if the neighbor's dog had leapt up onto the table and loudly gave him his first present of the day right on the table.

"Aren't you sooo lucky today's your birthday?"

Shinya sneered and glared evilly up at Takuya, "Gimme cereal."

"Yeah, I thought so," Takuya smirked as he took Shinya's plate and swept the pile of ashes into the garbage can.

At one point, the pile of ashes that was once toast destined to be devoured was now doomed to a dark and cramped fate at the bottom of a garbage bag. Takuya contemplated that slightly depressing thought as he began to open the fridge for some milk.

The refrigerator light spilled out through the room- it was still a little dark out since it was very early, and there was limited light- they still could see the room pretty good, though.

"I bet you wish the refrigerator light wasn't on all the time," Shinya sneered.

"Uhm, where did that come from?" Takuya asked.

"Well..." Shinya explained, "If I recall correctly, Mom and Dad caught you having a midnight snack last week all because the refrigerator light went on and blew your cover."

"Yeah, you have a point there," Takuya admitted, "But the refrigerator light isn't on all the time. It only turns on when you open the refrigerator door."

Shinya's eyes widened as if the purpose of life had suddenly been revealed to him in an instant flash, "What?!?" His face took on a quality of blatant denial, "No! You're wrong! It stays on forever!"

"Well, I'll have you know it doesn't!" Takuya said, closing the door, sealing any sign of light or absence of light away.

"Nuh-uh!" Shinya yelled, "You just can't see the light when you close the door like you just did!"

"Well, actually you just can't see the light turn off when you close the door!" Takuya retorted.

"But when you close the door, you close off the light, it doesn't shut off! You're so dumb, Takuya, what's going to shut the light off? There's no switch!"

"Shinya!" Takuya called his brother's name, "I'm telling you- How much do you wanna bet that this light turns off when I close the door?" Takuya asked as he opened and closed the door again, grinning. He got into fights like this with his brother almost every day.

"Uhm! Uhm!" Shinya hesistated with aggitation, "Uhm!"

"I bet'cha can't prove it!" Takuya cried, "I bet'cha can't even find something to bet on!"

"Well, I... I..." Shinya stammered, nervously looking around the room for something and sweating.

"I bet'cha I can eat more cake than you!" Shinya exclaimed loudly, jumping out of his seat and grinning with satisfaction.

Of course, thought Takuya, his eyes darts to the biggest target in the room.

"Well, I'm not sure about that, Shinya, Mom and Dad really want to celebrate your special day with you- I mean REALLY want to celebrate your birthday. Maybe we should wait until they-"

"You're afraid, aren't you, HUH, Takuya?" Shinya smirked, crossing his arms as he stood up, "You won't do it 'cause you're chicken you'll lose!"

"I'm not afraid!" Takuya cried, feeling the challenge and will to take it on building up in him. He would NOT be shown up by his little, bratty brother, Shinya.

His fists shook with rage as Shinya stuck his tongue out at him, "Nyaaah!" He was such a brat... Takuya HAD to prove that he could be better than his brother.

Takuya suddenly grabbed his plate and fork and handed Shinya a knife to make the first cut of the cake with, "Make your wish, little bro! You're going down!"
1412.title: Shinya's Birthday and a Dumb Challenge.

14121.content:
Shinya smirked, the fires of competition dancing in his youthful eyes.

"Forget the knife!" He shouted, throwing the aforementioned utensil behind him where it bounced off the wall and fell to the floor with a clatter.

Shinya then, much to Takuya's amazement, began digging into the monstrosity of a cake with only his hands.

"Shinya! W-What do you think you're doing?!" Takuya exclaimed, setting his own fork and plate aside.

Shinya paused for a moment and grinned up at his older brother, chocolate and frosting strewn all across his face.

"Eating my birthday cake. It takes to long to use a fork." He replied simply while Takuya just blankly stared at him. "I'd start eating to, if you want to win that is."

Takuya was about to speak up that Shinya was being stupid, but then he saw Shinya's eyes, an unspoken challenge.

Takuya gulped. And there was still no way he was letting his midget of a brother show him up when it came to eating, even if it was his special day.

Sweating a little, Takuya pulled up a chair and began stuffing himself as well. He had to admit; his mother definitely knew how to pick out a cake.

Takuya glanced up to see how his brother was faring and was disappointed to see that he was keeping up with his older brother quite nicely. If there was one thing about the Kanbara Brothers it was that they liked their food.

Fortunately, though Takuya was indeed a vacuum for food, he burned quite a bit of it off when he played soccer. Therefore, Takuya had remained quite thin all of his life. Though lately, he HAD been slacking off of practice, and he HAD been overeating perhaps just a bit...that's actually why his parents had been trying to limit his food intake as of lately, but Takuya had noticed any change in himself. HE hadn't gained any weight, and it wasn't like he was going to blow up to 700 pounds overnight.

Takuya rolled his eyes at the thought.

Soccer was also the one thing he had that Shinya didn't. While Shinya was most definitely the brainy one, he didn't have an athletic bone in his body, and preferred spending his free time indoors. Due to this, Shinya was a little bit thicker than Takuya, an had a few more curves, though with an appetite rivaling his own, Takuya wondered how Shinya had kept from inflating to the size of an elephant.

Now that Takuya thought about it, it could have been that, while both boys appetites were tremendous, Takuya ate more fatty foods, while Shinya had a more balanced diet, though he obviously had a sweet tooth from the way he was practically inhaling his birthday cake, like most small children did.

Takuya quickly glanced at the rest of the cake and growled.

He had caught up with Shinya, the young boy having a head start when Takuya had been slightly startled by using his hands as utensils, but the boys were now neck and neck. Both had devoured about a third of the bottom layer of the cake and were still eating with no signs of slowing down soon.

In the far recesses of his mind, Takuya cursed himself. He'd gotten himself into a real sticky situation. And there were still four layers of the cake to go.

He just hoped that wherever his mom was that is was crowded.

**************************************************

3 hours, 2 gallons of milk, and 4 layers of cake later...

Takuya groaned as his tried to massage his belly and relieve it at least somewhat from the pain it was currently in.

Across the kitchen, Shinya belched. The younger Kanbara brother was in no better shape compared to his older brother and was stretched out on the floor also rubbing his distended belly.

Takuya, in a similar position, almost felt sorry for his younger brother.

They had finished the cake, the giant, gargantuan, beast of a cake. It had taken two gallons of milk and all of Takuya's willpower, but he had done it; and he had won.

Shinya had conceded defeat halfway through the second to last layer, both had slowed down their pace considerably since the beginning of the contest, and Takuya had been left with the pleasure of devouring the last layer, though it was quite small- about the size of a normal pie and thinner than the other layers.

'Well...maybe not pleasure...' Takuya thought and strained to get up as his stomach gurgle. He had known he had won once Shinya stopped eating, but had felt it necessary to eat the last bit of the cake to illustrate his victory to Shinya…. looking back now, perhaps it hadn’t been the best idea…

“I’m never going to eat anything again…” Takuya moaned, finally managing to sit up.

Takuya then gulped, after taking in the kitchen, Shinya, and himself.
The kitchen was a disaster zone. There were pieces and crumbs of cake and frosting almost everywhere and Shinya had spilt a milk jug once leaving a rather large puddle of it trailing off of the table and into the floor.

Shinya and himself didn’t look any better. Both of their clothes were chocolate-stained and their faces were still covered with frosting and cake. Not to mention that their stomachs were stretched to capacity with cake and milk and had long since freed themselves from their constricting nightshirts.

Suddenly, Takuya panicked.

‘I cannot believe…. that we ate the WHOLE cake…Mom and Dad are gonna be sooo mad…’ He thought as he frantically tried to clean up the kitchen.

Ironically, and much to Takuya’s misfortune it was at that moment that his parents decided to come through the door, presents piled high in their arms and with a screech of “Happy Birthday, Shinya!”.

Then they saw the mess. The crumbs, the milk, the frosting, Shinya practically passed out on the floor, and Takuya smiling cheesily in the middle of it all and looking as if he had swallowed a watermelon.

They were calmed long enough to put Shinya’s presents down before commencing into a howling fit of rage.

“Takuya!” His mother said sharply, her arms crossed. “I want an explanation this instant!”

“What happened to you?! What happened to Shinya!? And most importantly, what happened two Shinya’s two hundred dollar birthday cake!?” Takuya’s father exclaimed, his face turning purple.

“Eheh…hehe…heh…well, that’s actually quite a funny story…” Takuya mumbled, scratching his head.

His parents continued to glare at him.

“Well…” Takuya began, shuffling his feet. “Shinya said it was his birthday and that he got whatever he wanted, and well…”

“Go on.” His father said sternly.

“We got into this argument about whether the light bulb in the refrigerator stays on or goes out when you close the door; Shinya said it always stayed on, but I knew better...and we argued some more and, um….he dared me to see who could eat most of his birthday cake…and I won” Takuya continued, once again trying to massage some of the pain away from his swollen gut.

For a moment Takuya and his parents shared a stony silence, with only the occasional moan from Shinya.

Then his father burst out laughing. His mother, however, gave him a stern look while she massaged her temples.

“Takuya, you know better than to lead your brother goad you like that- if he did. I’m going to ask him when he...wakes up, I suppose. But either way, you’re supposed to be a good example for your brother. Plus, you’re starting to get lazier and lazier. You’re up two pounds from two months ago! That’s a pound a month! DO you want to end up like all those fat teenagers in America?” Takuya’s mom lectured, before turning and elbowing her husband. “This is no laughing matter. Shinya’s already quite paunchy, do you want Takuya to end up like that as well?”

Takuya rolled his eyes. His mother had a phobia of fat. He supposed it came from when she was a child; she herself had been overweight and had been teased for it. She had eventually lost the weight, but was terrified of her family packing on the pounds, thus the monthly weighing and her often references to how fat kids and teenagers in America were. Takuya had told her he’d want to be a sumo wrestler once as a joke and she had actually fainted.

Takuya’s father coughed to stifle his laughter, but an amused twinkle was still in his eye.

“Your mother’s right, Takuya. IT was quite irresponsible of you and Shinya to eat his… two hundred dollar cake…” His father trailed off a moment, paling a bit. “And you don’t want to get fat do you?”

“No, Dad.” Takuya replied after another roll of his eyes.

“Good. But we’re punishing you. You’re grounded for two weeks.” His mother stated more calmly than she had been previously.

“But what about Shinya!” Takuya exclaimed and pointed to his brother, still in a sugar-induced coma.

“It’s his birthday.” His mother replied simply, picking up said birthday boy and taking him into the bathroom to get cleaned up. “I don’t want to speak about this anymore Takuya.”

Takuya scowled and stormed off towards his room, leaving his father in the disaster area that was the kitchen.

Takuya growled as he just leaned against his closed door for a moment, thinking of how unfair his parents had been.

‘Shinya’s the won who dared be! The brat..’ Takuya thought to himself, but was suddenly interrupted when…
14121.title: The Contest of the Cake

141212.content:
Takuya heard a synthesized ringing sound coming from his nightstand, on the upper right hand corner of his bed, catching him by surprise and making him sweat and jerk nervously a little.

As he lunged towards the nightstand, his belly churned and remember that it was completely filled up with expanded cake that probably absorbed a good deal of the milk he had downed. With it sloshing around in his belly, it caused a good deal of nausea, and he had to be careful until his stomach settled.

Takuya's threw out his hand and grabbed the knob of the nightstand, pulling out the door, removing the cell phone, and opening it up, causing the ringing to cease. He hoped his parents hadn't heard it because it would be just another thing for them to take away during his grounding.

A question came into Takuya's head as he sat down on his bed with cell phone in hand- who would really be calling him at this time? He was pretty sure that most of his friends were away on vacation or busy, and aside from them, no one else knew his cell phone number.

Takuya's eyes widened as he read an unfamiliar cell phone screen.

It displayed: 'You have recieved a new cell phone message. The following (1) message(s) is from *USER UNKNOWN*. Would you like to read this message?'

It was from an unknown sender... and it was a message, not a call. He had never recieved a message, not once, and he wasn't sure whether to open it or not. It might as well have been an ad, spam, or maybe even a virus.

But Takuya, being the bold, adventurous individual he was, gave the cell phone the OK to recieve the message. Besides, he was going to get bored very soon, he had nothing better to do now that he was grounded, and, well, he was just plain curious as to what the message was.

'Takuya Kanbara: It's time to decide your future. Your destiny is calling you. Take the 7:45 outbound train at the Shibuya Station. Further instructions shall await you there.'

Takuya read the message again before glancing up at the clock, also on his nightstand. It was around 2:30. Then, Takuya saved the message before snapping his cell phone shut. Clutching the cell phone tightly in his hands, he sighed deeply and fell back heavily onto his bedspread.

What was going on here?

First of all, it was very interesting that he had recieved such a message. But what did it really mean? Sure, it told him to go to that certain train at that certain time... but what did the part about him deciding his future and his destiny calling him mean?

Maybe he had won some kind of contest... but he hadn't entered any that he knew of.

Perhaps some secret admirer was going to meet him there... and that really got Takuya's hopes up about the whole prospect.

It could be that the message was sent by some crazy hacker or killer... but that was just the kind of worried thinking that his mom usually did. His mom, the one who kept records of her sons' weights in a safe next to her tax records.

Takuya sighed as he thought the whole thing through over again in simplistic terms. Perhaps it was some kind of greater calling... perhaps it was even aliens, or something had he just quite couldn't explain.

The more he thought about it, the more he wanted to do it... and the more he thought about it, the more fantastic his dreams became about what would happen at the Shibuya Train Station, and the more he thought about it, the more he forgot that he was grounded. Suddenly, that nasty little thought breached his mind.

It was about 3:45, and Takuya Kanbera grabbed his head and moaned as his belly gurgled. The house was, for the most part, empty as his parents had taken Shinya either out to lunch or shopping- Takuya didn't understand why because Shinya already had his presents and he probably had enough cake in him to last him a lifetime.

Even without the whole destiny mythos attached to the message, the pleasant thought of running away from home flourished in Takuya's mind. Even if that train went nowhere in particular, he bet he could still live a better life away from home for a week or two, or just until his grounding terms had expired.

He opened his cell phone again, and eagerly read the message. His destiny was waiting for him at 7:45, and probably, at that time, his parents and Shinya would be back... He could leave for the station now and make it! He could slip right out the door.

Cell phone in hand, Takuya twisted the doorknob of the door in front of his room and peered outwards when the door was open just a crack. The coast was clear. As he tiptoed rapidly down the hallway, he made his way right to the front door, opened it up, and his eyes widened.

A cool summer breeze blew straight towards Takuya. The winds reminded him that he was not ready at all to go to the train station. These divine winds also helped him realize a number of things.

1. He really wasn't prepared for a trip to the station, never mind a trip to wherever the train was going.

2. Even if he made it right now, he would still have to wait at the station for the train.

3. His parents would notice that he was gone before the train left.

4. If he tried to run away, it wouldn't be much better than life at home because he was broke!

5. He was still in his boxers.

Takuya then decided to withdraw to his room for the moment. He also became determined in his mind that he would take the train for sure...

He would spend the remainder of the day preparing, packing his backpack with necessities, and getting ready for the journey ahead. Nobody would really bother him because he was grounded and Shinya was supposed to be in the spotlight of the world today, right?

***

Takuya glanced up at the clock, "5:58 PM," he noted as he read it. He had just about everything ready, but he was nervous and excited as ever!

Both his parents and Shinya had returned from their destination: the cell phone shop to get Shinya the newest and most up-to-date cell phone as an extra birthday surprise. Takuya had the pleasure and torture of listening to Shinya try out billions of ring tones over... and over... and over again.

And of course, Shinya had burst into his room unexpectedly and frequently with his new cell phone or one of his new toys, showing off and smiling and bragging about how much more fun he was having. Takuya noted that Shinya's belly as well as his own wasn't as swollen and tight as before, as some digestion had gone on during all those hours. However, Takuya wouldn't have been so surprised if they put on some flab on their frames since then.

Luckily, since Shinya was gloating so much, he didn't really see Takuya slip the backpack he was packing away into the shadows or a closet.

Takuya simply nodded, agreed that Shinya was having a much better time than him, and made a critical evaluation of the current ring tone, making sure to include comparisons to previously displayed ring tones that Shinya had asked him about.

Deep in a corner of his mind as Shinya left, Takuya smirked to himself. Surely he was going to have a much better time once he got to the train station. Something was going to happen there, something great- he could feel it!

The feelings of anticipation grew flying in him, pulsating vividly with life. It's a strange feeling of optimism one usually feels when looking forward to something with great anticipation. It's a feeling that almost pats your back, shakes your hand and tells you, "It's gonna all get better for sure, the best of the day has yet to come, I can tell you that for sure!"

And Takuya knew for sure that the best of the day was yet to come at 7:45 tonight at the Shibuya Train Station. He smiled as he read through the message again. Either this was truly fate or he was making a big deal of it all because he was extremely bored.

***
6:15 P.M.

"Toothbrush, check!" Takuya said to himself as he put the afforementioned item into a plastic bag to go into his backpack and checked the corresponding checkbox on the supply list he had made.

"Toothpaste, check," he noted as he put the tube of mint toothpaste he shared with his brother. He'd have to deal with it. Besides, he probably got some for his birthday anyway.

"Comb, check." Although it probably wouldn't do him much good, he put the black, plastic toothed comb in the large, refrigerator-sized plastic bag
he managed to pilfer from underneath the sink when nobody was looking. It was messily labled 'Toiletries' in his own scrawly penmanship with a black permanent marker he had scrounged up from his desk.

"And... toilet paper," Takuya read off as he skimmed through the final section of the list, "And that completes toiletries, which in turn is the last section of the list! I'm done!"

As Takuya walked back into his bedroom, he closed the door behind him. At the center of his room was his backpack, looking just as stuffed as he had been that morning. He struggled to fit the plastic bag into the backpack, and after a bit of a fight, succeeded as he zipped it over and patted it, "All set," he grinned as he hefted it over his body. It must have weighed about a ton, but he had packed everything he thought he'd need on a train ride, perhaps even to run away.

He was ready for sure, but his dad was still home at the living room, reading the newspaper. His mom, on the other hand, had gone out to the pharmacy because she suddenly discovered the family was almost out of cough syrup.

Takuya couldn't try to sneak past his dad, he'd notice him for sure, or Shinya would before him, even still. What he needed was an excuse, and a good one at that.

He could always say that he had left his homework at home and needed to take a bus to the school and open up his locker- but that would never work. He'd always use that excuse when he wanted to get out at night, and especially now it was a well known fact in the Kanbera residence that Takuya's school was closed over the summer.

He could... he could try and tell his dad that he still had to get Shinya a birthday present. It was true, he hadn't gotten him anything, and Shinya would be sure to complain about it- but then his dad would probably offer to take him out to get a present later or when he wasn't grounded.

That excuse was satisfactory and true, but still, he needed to get out and to the train station without his parents. He needed to get Shinya a present... something that required him leaving the house without Dad.

He got an inkling of an idea... but no, it was a sacrifice on his part... still, it was the strongest possibility out there if he wanted to get to the train station on time...

6:34 P.M

What he would do in this secondary plan is tell his dad that he had yet to give Shinya a present, just like before... except this time, he would say that he felt bad about spoiling Shinya's birthday and wanted to make it up to him by taking him fishing out on the pond a few blocks down.

The big con in this plan, the really big con was having to have Shinya tag along. Having to bring Shinya, the biggest pain in the rearend along with him on his mysterious destiny train ride seemed impossible... but he made it all possible. Was this truly his destiny?

The only pro Takuya could see was that Shinya was probably loaded with birthday money. Money: the one thing on Takuya's list that he had yet to collect. Still, Shinya probably wouldn't let Takuya have any of the money, and he would probably tattle on him because he for sure carried and guarded his brand new cell phone. Takuya wondered if Shinya would get a message like he did if it was just a message that was sent to everyone's cell phones...

The cons still overshadowed the single pro... yet there was still a chance, there was still that glimmer of hope that it just might work, that chance that Takuya would make it to the train on time, that Takuya would discover his fate and destiny.

Well, there were two options from here: Takuya could use the excuse about having to leave by himself to get Shinya a present... or he could use the excuse of taking Shinya out to fish to make it up to him on his birthday.

But what would Takuya say?
141212.title: Planning for the Train Ride.

144.content:
With a brief flash of the stage lights, a loud crack emitted from the stage. Instantly, the stage floor burst into dim, blue and red clouds that drifted quietly outwards towards the audience.

The stage lights spun up and down, casting beams of light first at the ceiling, then slowly crossing each other, and descending down to the stage floor, where a shadowy figure rose up on a platform. A deep voiced narrator introduced the performer to the audience, "You may have seen him in the movies or television, but never like this. Ladies and gentlemen, introducing J.P. Shibayama in his very special, first live performance."

Suddenly, the stage lights cast down upon the figure now standing in the middle of the dark stage and illuminated the figure, revealing a somewhat thin and muscular boy with auburn hair and warm, brown eyes. He was wearing a red bowtie, white vest, and black jacket and pants.

The young adult known as J.P. began to sweat as he looked out to the hundreds of faces sitting in the theatre seats. It was worlds away from shooting movies or commercials, where he had made his name in fame. Not only was it his first time doing a live performance, but it was also his first time doing a magic show, something he had always dreamed about doing since he was a kid.

"Uhm, hi..." J.P. smiled nervously, placing a hand behind his back as he broke out into a heavy sweat, his hundreds of lines memorized in the rehearsals suddenly vanishing in his memory bank, "I guess you all want to know what my first trick is, right?" he asked weakly.

J.P. mentally slapped himself. What about all the jokes and funny lines he had worked on to start the show with a bang to complement the special effects and voice-over announcer?

He decided he'd give the jokes a shot, trying to remember a good line to break the ice...

"So, uh, I could never get a girl when I was younger so... no, wait, sorry... I could never go on a... Actually, I had it right the first time, I could never get a girl to like me when I was younger because..."

J.P. began to shiver as he got silence and a few coughs, "...well, let's say there wasn't any reason..." He forgot the second part of the joke... and he had just fallen flat on his face.

He took a deep breath, wiped his face with a hankerchief, hoped the audience wouldn't see his shaking limbs, and prayed that all the tricks and magic would still work subconciously throughout his performance, regardless of his nervousness.

"Alright," J.P. smiled cheesily, rubbing his hands together, "So, let's start on those tricks, then, right?"

He recieved nothing more but cold silence.

J.P. decided to cut to the chase and perform one of his more flashier tricks, leaving the less impressive, introductory card tricks for later: he'd start off his repetoire with a bang, hopefully erasing the little fumble he made towards the beginning of the act from the audience's memories.

"So... for my first magic trick, I will require two volunteers," J.P. stated, while mysterious, dark clothed stage hands quickly set up his materials, rolling out and assembling a collapsible table behind him for later, placing an oblong box on top of it after they were finished. J.P., of course, couldn't pay attention to any of this as he had to focus his efforts towards the audience and pick some volunteers, "Let's see..." he contemplated, "You there, in the front row," he called, pointing to a brown haired boy in the front row. The stage lights soon revealed he was wearing a brightly colored red jacket over a yellow t-shirt and had a rather suprised and excited look on his face.

"And, uh..." J.P. faltered as he saw who he had randomly picked in the audience before shrugging and continuing, "You, in the far back row," he said, pointing to the farthest back, most dark, shady figure he could still discern from in the dark audience. The lights shone down and uncovered that his second victim looked rather indifferent to the fact that he had been chosen, and continued to glare with his dark eyes towards the stage with his arms crossed. He had dark hair styled in a ponytail, wore a bandana and blue clothing over a yellow t-shirt as well.

J.P.'s eyes slightly widened, his mouth agape when he realized the identities of his two volunteers; Takuya and Kouji! He remembered them somehow... yes, he remembered now. They must have been his friends from before he started his life of fame, "Come on up, Takuya and Kouji," he grinned, calling the two to the stage. Within minutes, the two boys had made their way to the stage. J.P. felt a little more enheartened now that somebody he actually knew was on stage.

"Now, I'm guessing both of you and the rest of the audience would like to know what exactly the first trick I will be performing is, right?" J.P. asked, laughing.

"Uhm, yeah," Takuya blinked, "You know, it might reassure us if you let us know right away whether you're going to cut us open or not, J.P."

The audience waited for Kouji's response for a while, but he just remained standing cool and silent, arms crossed, his eyes still glaring, except this time at the audience.

"Heh," J.P. grinned, "Ladies and gentlemen, for those who may not know, luck would have it that I selected two of my friends from the audience, and if there's one thing I can assure you of, it's that this was not planned or premeditated at all! How about that?"

That won a mild applause from the audience. It must have been a tough crowd that night...

"So, for my first trick, I will make one of you guys disappear!" J.P. cried, whipping out a slim, black wand from his pocket. It wasn't his speciality, and he knew for a fact he could have spent a bit more time practicing it, but he was firing up the audience's attention and enthusiasm, so he wanted to continue as strong as possible, even if it meant taking a risky chance.

First, he pointed the wand at Kouji, who slightly raised an eyebrow in interest, not seeming to care on a whole at all, then J.P. pointed it at Takuya, who held up his hands in defense and squeemed a little under pressure, "Who will it be? The audience will decide!" J.P. cried to his audience, before pointing the wooden wand to Kouji, then Takuya, "Kouji or Takuya? Who will it be?"

Less than a moment later, the audience all unanimously roared:
144.title: All But Disappearing...

choices: Kouji and Takuya quite apparent and seemingly unaffected by the spell.
-something had happened to the two boys.
1442.content:
At first, a few members of the audience started to cry out the name of the boy they wanted to see have a spell cast upon and disappear. Soon, more and more people began shouting out and chanting one of the two names, however as the momentum for cheering names grew, one name emerged as the victor of the short-lived battle of cheers.

"Kouji! Kouji! Kouji!" the audience chanted, some throwing their fists into the air in beat with the chant. The dark haired boy raised his eyebrows, scowled, and rolled his eyes almost apathetically with his mouth slightly agape when he heard the audience's response.

"Well, you've heard it, then, folks," JP smiled nervously, mindful that he hadn't been studying up on his stageshow magic tricks, the disappearing act being the worst of them, "Kouji Minamoto is our lucky guy who will be the first volunteer of this show!" The audience cheered in response. The boy in blue mumbled something to himself before sighing, putting his hands in his pockets, and closing his eyes.

"... Do I really have to go through with this?" he asked through closed teeth.

"Well, yeah, there's nothing dangerous involved about it if that's what you're worrying about," JP assured his reluctant volunteer, amidst the audience's loud and overly enthusiastic cheers.

Kouji just turned his head down, smirked darkly, and sighed again, "Whatever you say, JP... but why they'd want to see me disappear over that numbskull Takuya..." before he chuckled, "I can see you're quite the success with the audience, JP."

JP smirked in return before turning to face his audience, "Let's just hope I can keep it up."

Beads of sweat ran down the young magician's forehead, "Uhm... ladies and gentlemen, for my first trick of the evening, I will make this boy, Kouji Minamoto disappear!"

Again, the audience broke out into mild applause as he said this. Two spotlights poured down from the iron framework above the stage onto Kouji and JP as all other lights began to fade out; Takuya frowned when he sensed that he was starting to get left in the dark on stage and started to grin cheesily while tiptoing and edging off slowly, closer and closer to Kouji's own circle of light so he could be better seen.

JP was now breaking out into a fine stream of sweat dripping from his face, "That's right, so, uh, let's begin!" he continued, trying not to stall any longer, and struggling to remember what little he could from the illusion. Was it the procedure where he sent a signal out to the stage hands above by waving his wand to send smoke and lights over where Kouji was so they could swiftly drop a small, dark curtain over Kouji's body. The curtain could blend in with the background, making it appear that he had disappeared... but he began to shiver as he considered all the possibility for failure he had during those few steps, as he had barely practiced this disappearing act alone, even with an unknowing volunteer. Hopefully, Kouji wouldn't try to walk past the curtain... but even still...

The fear of failure started to consume JP's thoughts as he rigidly stood on stage, facing JP. Reluctantly, he grabbed his black magic wand from the dark box on the collapsible table, located conviently next to him. He could feel that not only his face was, at this point, cold and dripping with sweat as he clutched the wand stiffly in his right hand... he was going to mess up completely on this and the whole show would fall apart... his reputation as a famous actor would be ruined, and all because of some failed magic trick... why did he ever get himself involved in this?

"Oh great," JP muttered to himself as he noticed that his shoelaces on one shoe were completely untied. He couldn't just bend over and retie them in front of an entire stadium full of people watching him. JP would have to make due.

It seemed like he was frozen with fright and had difficulty moving... as if he couldn't continue the show because JP knew all eyes were on him... scrutinizing and watching for any little slip-up he might make...

"Uhm..." Kouji said, raising an eyebrow while he stood cooly with his hands hidden away into his pockets, "Are you going to say any magic words or wave your wand, or what?"

JP suddenly stood upright, "Magic words..." he gasped, taking a spare hankerchief out and wiping the sweat off his forehead, "Ah, I suppose... I mean..."

He was stalling again! JP was sure he heard a few murmurs again throughout the crowd, and especially after he had gotten them all fired up...

If only he could somehow leave this tricky scenario... all eyes were on him... he wanted to sit down, placing a hand against his face, breath deeply and relax, relieving him of this predicament...

"You know, magic words?" Takuya piped in, sticking his head into Kouji's spotlight, making only his head visible to the audience, "Like 'Hocus Pocus!' " he yelled, jumping into the middle of Kouji's ring of light on the stage, throwing his arms out with much gusto, and nearly bumping into Kouji. "Or 'Alakazam!' he continued, waving his fingers in the air.

The two boys now shared the same spotlight, "Yeah, sure, Takuya, whatever you say..." Kouji snickered.

"Well, isn't somebody having a 'cooler-than-thou' attitude tonight, Kouji," Takuya cried, "Maybe it's a good thing you'll be disappearing tonight, if not just for a little while."

Takuya glanced upwards and placed a finger on his chin after a while with thought, "But you do have a good point. Those magic words are all generic ones, you know, stuff you hear in jokes and cartoons. Maybe JP has a real disappearing spell that he can work on you!" This got a few cheers from the audience, but most of them were paying attention to the two boys more than the troubled JP, who shifted from side to side, not sure what to do, "Well, what's the word, then?" Takuya asked.

"Uhm!" JP snapped to attention, trying to win the audience, walking toward the boys.

Suddenly, JP fell flat on his face with a crash!

His head spinning and seeing stars, JP slowly rose from the sleek, polished floor, bending a knee. Everyone was laughing at him, even Takuya, and some cheered. In fact, the only person who JP was sure wasn't laughing at him was Kouji, and even he was grinning! "Uhm, oops?" JP laughed nervously, pretending to smile and act like nothing had gone wrong at all. He felt horrible and extremely embarassed as his face began to turn a vivid shade of red. He got the audience's attention after all, didn't he? ... Truly, he wanted out. It was a mess-up; if only he could just rewind and start from the beginning again, if only he could redo the act!

Suddenly a burst of smoke and flares exploded out of JP's wooden wand with a loud bang that cracked through the laughter, silencing everyone! The bunch of strangely forming smoke and sparkles shot out toward a wide-eyed Kouji and Takuya and soon engulfed them to the audience's awe; some gasped and others just watched intently to see what would happen...

Within a matter of moments that stood on end and seemed to last hours, the strange clouds cleared and dissolved slowly into the air, revealing...
1442.title: Nothing Up His Sleeves...

choices: Behind stage, the producer goes over the changes in the show
145.content:
"-and we're going to let the pasta boil from anywhere from six to ten minutes- the longer you keep it on, the more tender they're going to be. I find that seven minutes tends to do the trick for me," a golden haired girl of medium height wearing a purple cooking apron smiled warmly as she stirred a steaming pot with a wooden spoon.

"Now, you want to make sure that you're stirring every now and again so the pasta doesn't stick to the sides," Zoe explained, making a few last vigorous stirs before tapping the wooden spoon as dry as she could and placing it on the countertop.

"Now, when we return back from the commercial break, everything will be ready to eat. Then, you'll get to hear what our panelist say about how my cooking turned out, "Now, with the remaining time we have before then, let's get to meet them," Zoe beamed radiantly with her brilliant blue eyes for her television audience as she walked over to a table covered in a red and white checkerboard-styled tablecloth.

Three boys sat next to each other at the judges table. Two of them looking nervously at the other as the large black camera's lens crossed path with their own eyes. However, the other boy, who sitted at the far right simply sighed and laced his fingers together and gaped at Zoe as she walked on screen to the far left of the table.

"So, tell me, who's our first judge, the dark looking guy sitting on the left?" Zoe asked, being sure to smile at him. She knew him, but needed to ask so the audience would be familar with him as well. The dark blue clad boy shivered at saccharine overload he had just took in.

"Uhm... my name's Kouji," he murmured, just barely loud enough for the camera equipment to pick up.

"Ah, I see," Zoe grinned, still a little unsure as to why Kouji would be on a cooking show, but she kept on nodding as she moved onto the next judge, "And, you are-" Zoe indicated to the next boy, who she recognized as being her friend. However her memories of him were clouded at best.

Suddenly, the boy in the middle wearing red and yellow, who Zoe knew as Takuya, grinned wider than she was and got a sudden burst of energy and courage to speak to the audience, "Hi everyone out there!" he cried, "My name's Takuya! I was the Shibuya Junior Eating Contest Champion last summer! I can down just as much as you put in front of my plate."

Suddenly, he calmed down and said almost as soft as Kouji, "It would be an honor to eat your pasta."

Zoe cringed as she saw the next boy, who she vaguely recalled had more than a yen for her, but not much more than that. Already, she could tell he still had similar sentiments as hearts appeared in his eyes while his jaw hung slack.

"Uhm, and you..."

"Did I ever tell you how beautiful you look with blush on? ..." the brown haired boy known as JP gasped slowly before the total blush on Zoe's face magnified and multiplied to from it was seconds ago. She placed cool hands on her cheeks, covering her lower face.

"Uhm... moving on..." Zoe glowered, her sheer embarassment turning to mild anger, "So that will be after the break. Until then: Li vedrò presto!"

The cameras rolled up and Zoe went off the set for a brief break before continuing filming. She didn't have to worry about the pasta. It was already steaming, prepared, and ready for her friends, the judges. The pasta that had been filmed and was already boiling would end up being her own lunch.

Zoe still couldn't believe that she persuaded the managers to allow her friends to guest judge on the show for the last episode of the season. However, she started to doubt and wonder her request after JP's certain... behavior on air...

Bumbling through the crowds of cameramen and technicians came a short, stubby looking man wearing thick horn-rimmed glasses. He was sporting a thin mustache and was currently panting, his hands resting on his knees. He got up, clutching a thick packet of paper.

"What's the matter?" Zoe asked. She usually wasn't approached by the producer of the show during filming, especially when on air- but judging by the look on his face and the size of the packet he held in his hand, Zoe knew this could mean only one thing... the one thing she was dreading since she walked in on the set.

"The ratings have come in," he said with a grim look on his face as he quickly ran a finger through the tops of the pages, "And I've got to say, I'm really shocked..."

Zoe twitched a little as she extended a hand to the packet nervously, "Oh... let me see! Are they good?"

"No! You have to film very soon- I wouldn't want you to..." the producer's hoarse voice wheezed cautiously as he pointed to the electric 'on-air' sign that had currently been turned off. Zoe looked at the producer with a sad look on her face, and it appeared that he would reconsider, "Alright... when does it come back on?"

A stage hand whispered into his ears as he nodded, his face relaxed, and he waved to Zoe that she was fine, "I don't want you to be anticipating anything while on air, so I might as well tell you anyway. Although, it was my fault that I let you know in the middle of a show, but it is kind of important..."

"Well, come on..." Zoe sighed tensely, "How did the ratings turn out?"

"Superb, well above and beyond our estimates... and that's an understatement," the producer stated quickly, "I have to say, Zoe, your cooking show has become a real success almost instantly. It's like we've struck instant T.V. gold- who would have thought that aiming a cooking show at a younger demographic would have been so... well, successful?"

"I don't know..." Zoe closed her eyes smiled, rubbing the back of her head, "Maybe teaching other kids how to make easy-to-cook stuff makes them a little bit more confident in their own abilities- I guess it just caught on." Zoe shrugged, "But that's just my guess."

"No, according to these reports, you're absolutely right," the producer exclaimed, "You're already gathering a very large regular audience. If we were to tweak and add one or two more things and integrate some popular elements into your show, it's definitely going to be the next really big thing- I'm talking about next big popular show genre... people have had their fill of soap operas, game shows, sitcoms, and reality shows..."

"But I don't understand. Cooking shows have been on for quite a while," Zoe said, a little confused.

"True, but remember our different demographic aim to a younger audience... but with the few tweaks I mentioned before, the show should be a new T.V. cooking experience altogether."

"I see..." Zoe said, before the light on the 'on-air' sign flared back on and the theme music started playing to cue her entry, "Oh- there I go," she grinned.

"So..." Zoe said, noticing that the boys had already dug in, "What do you guys think?"

"It's pretty good..." Kouji muttered as he nibbled on the pasta on his fork.

"Aw man, this is the greatest..." Takuya exclaimed as he shoveled mouthful after mouthful away, "I've got to tell ya," he mumbled with his mouth full, "You really know how to cook good food."

"Why thank you..." Zoe smiled slightly, "And you, J-" she was cut off when she saw that JP had barely touched his pasta and was resting his head on his hands and staring affectionately at Zoe.

"It's pretty good. I like it," JP sighed, "But you know what I like even more? -"

"Okay!" Zoe blushed wildly again as she motioned to turn the cameras away. Her mouth and eyes twitched a little before she continued, "Alright, so that's all for today..." she said hastily, "I, uhm... I'll see you next time? ..."

"Aaand... fade out," sounded the voice of the director as Zoe ran offstage, her face still a little flushed and warm.
145.title: Zoe's Cooking Show

choices: J.P., only a little bigger than normal.

Cherubimon smiled maliciously as the thought formed in his head. He would change time itself, making the human children to have always been fat. He then frowned slightly. Doing this would require great power, for even his power would wane. He would have to make use of his Dark Warriors...and perhaps even...Lucemon. "We shall alter the very course of time." He then said causing some to gasp out in shock. "My Lord..." Mercurymon began, "Begging your pardon, but not even thou hast that kind of power." Cherubimon surprised everyone by nodding. "Which is why we shall ALL offer our power...to call upon Lucemon. Everyone gasped again. "l-Lucemon?!" Ranamon stammered. "B-but he's sealed in the center of the Digital World!" Cherubimon nodded again. "And he was sealed there by the Ten Legendary Warriors, Five of which whose powers you posses. If you weaken the seal, and I offer some of my power, I'm sure that Lucemon would aid us." The Dark Warriors glanced around nervously. It was dangerous, but it could definately work. "Sir..." Duskmon startled everyone by speaking, something he rarely did. "Will...our pasts be affected?" Cherubimon looked at Duskmon, for what seemed like for a second, suspiscion, but quickly hid it. "No. The humans will be taken back to the point of entering the Digital World at Shibuya Station. The spell will have caused their past to have altered, and while they will have faint memories of this time, we shall remember it clearly. Basically, its just a...repitition, only they're going to be fat." Cherubimon finished his explanation and the others nodded in understanding. "Position yourselves around me and we shall call Lucemon." Cherubimon ordered, making sure everyone was positioned correctly, and began to chant. "O, Supreme Dark Lord Lucemon! We call upon you in hopes of destroying those who follow the path of Good!" A Dark Aura then gathered around the evil digimon. "Aid your evil brethren by granting our wish with your Demonic Power!!" Then the Dark Warriors began to glow. "I offer my power unto you, as do the Warriors of Steel, Water, Ground, Wood, and Darkness!" A white light then engulfs Cherubimon and flows out, over the Dark Warriors, over Cherubimon's Castle, over the Digital world, over the camp of a certain group of human children, blinding all..

15.title: Changing the Past...

151.content:
Takuya was no longer a skinny kid, but instead he weighed in at about 230 lbs. His face was rounder and he almost had a double chin. His belly was easily the biggest part of him and stuck out about a foot. It looked like a big ball and sometimes it jiggled when he walked.

His clothes were also bigger than before because Takuya had always been fat now. His red jacket and yellow shirt might have fit J.P before Cherubimon changed the past.

Takuya's arms were also flabby and smooth, his legs were as big around as plates. But Takuya was panting now and he looked sad.

"They...keep on chasing me... because I'm... fat?" Takuya gasped with his chubby hands on his knees, "That doesn't make sense." Takuya had always wanted to play soccer, but the other kids wouldn't let him because he was too fat and slow. Now they had chased him to the train station.

Suddenly, Takuya's cell phone started to ring.
"Hmm? What's this?" he said as he pulled it out of his pocket.
151.title: Takuya

choices: A boy in dark blue, about the same weight as him.
A small kid ravenously eating some candy.
1511.content:
"Hmmm..." Takuya wondered as he watched his cell phone. It had a strange emblem on it currently,...but the image was fuzzy and becoming darker...was it a virus? 'No.' Takuya thought, pushing some buttons with his chubby fingers. He hadn't done anything for one to be activated. It was probably his mom. She had told him to take out the trash, but that was when a group of bullies, a few jocks from Takuya's School, began chasing him, and he ended up here. Takuya then ran a fat hand through his hair. It was his brother Shinya's birthday today, too. He then chuckled softly. His mom and cooked a huge dinner in honor of her "big-eleven-year-old" yesterday. "Not again..." Tommy sighed, "Oh well... there's always next week..." Suddenly, his cell phone began to ring, "Oh no! Please don't let it be Mom!" Tommy cried, grabbing for his cell phone.
154.title: Tommy
